characters: OVER THESE OBJECTS, THE REST OF THE CREDIT TITLES ARE

dialogues.speaker: BRASS PLAQUE
dialogues.text: Engraved on it are the words: COX & CO., Bankers. Reflected in its shiny surface are double-decker red buses, and other present-day London traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An iron gate opens, and two bank guards come in. One of them switches on the lights. On the shelves which line the walls are dusty strong-boxes, document cases, wrapped packages, etc. The guards move along the shelves searching for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somewhere in the vaults of a bank in London is a tin dispatch box with my name on it. It is not to be opened until fifty years after my death. The guards find a battered tin dispatch box with the name JOHN H. WATSON, M.D., painted on it. They remove it from the shelf, set it down on a table. The box is tied with heavy cord, the knots sealed with wax. Strung on the cord is the key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It contains certain mementos of my long association with a man who elevated the science of deduction to an art -- the world's first, and undoubtedly most famous, consulting detective. While one of the guards dusts the box off, the other cuts the cord with a pair of scissors. He then inserts the key in the lock, turns it, raises the lid -- revealing the dusty contents of the box. OVER THIS, SUPERIMPOSE THE MAIN TITLE. The guards now start to remove the objects from the box, one at a time: -- A daguerreotype of Holmes, standing, and Watson, seated, in a a stiff studio pose; Holmes' deerstalker hat, his curved pipe, his magnifying glass; Watson's stethoscope, Holmes' revolver; a small enamel sign with the number 221B; a pair of handcuffs;

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a sheet of music paper which is unrolled to disclose a violin piece composed by Holmes, titled FOR ILSE von H.; A pocket watch, the back of which is opened to reveal a photograph of Gabrielle Valladon; a signet ring bearing the initials S.H. -- under which is concealed a compass; a worn morocco case -- inside which is an early-model hypodermic syringe; a crystal ball which, when shaken, produces a snowstorm - and when the snow settles, we see a bust of Queen Victoria.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSED.
dialogues.text: The last item out of the box   is a thick stack of manuscript paper, bound with   green ribbon. The guard undoes the ribbon, dusts off   the top page, as CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSER.  Written in   ink, in the cursive penmanship of the period, is   the following paragraph: To my heirs: In my lifetime, I have recorded some sixty cases demonstrating the singular gift of my friend Sherlock Holmes -- dealing with everything from The Hound of the Baskervilles to his mysterious brother Mycroft and the devilish Professor Moriarty. But there were other adventures which, for reasons of discretion, I have decided to withhold from the public until this much later date. They involve matters of a delicate and sometimes scandalous nature, as will shortly become apparent. OVER THIS, WE HEAR THE VOICE OF DR. WATSON, reading the text.

dialogues.speaker: YORKSHIRE LANDSCAPE
dialogues.text: A passenger train of the late Nineteenth Century is chugging through the early morning mist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was August of 1887, and we were returning from Yorkshire, where Holmes had solved the baffling murder of Colonel Abernetty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are but two passengers in the compartment -- sitting by the window, facing each other. In fact they are dozing. One wears a deerstalker and an Inverness cape; the other is in a dark overcoat and a black bowler, a furled umbrella between his legs, a medical bag on the seat beside him. The rest of their luggage is on the racks above. They are, of course, SHERLOCK HOLMES and DR. JOHN H. WATSON. This being 1887, they are thirty- three and thirty-five respectively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may recall that he broke the murderer's alibi by measuring the depth to which the parsley had sunk in the butter on a hot day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hansom cab, with Holmes' and Watson's luggage strapped to the rack on top, is proceeding down the busy street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was the most brilliant man I have ever known -- and I dare say people have envied me for sharing that flat with him in Baker Street. The cab draws up   in front of 221B. The front door opens and MRS. HUDSON,   a plump, motherly woman in her fifties wearing an apron,   hurries down the steps. She greets Holmes and Watson   warmly as they alight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll grant you he was stimulating -- but he could also be moody, unpredictable, egocentric, and more often than not, completely infuriating -- as our landlady, Mrs. Hudson, can attest -- bless her kind soul. The cabbie   starts to unload their luggage. As Holmes, Watson and   Mrs. Hudson proceed inside, CAMERA TRAVELS U THE FACADE   OF THE BUILDING, past the number 221B, to th bay window   on the second floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all there -- the fireplace, the coal scuttle, the Persian slipper with the tobacco; the velvet wing chair, the basket chair with the writing-arm, the couch with the cushions; the sideboard with the tantalus and the gasogene; the acid-stained deal-topped table with Holmes' chemical equipment on it, the dining table, the small Moorish table; the bookshelves and the violin case; the gas fixtures and the oil lamps; the dumbwaiter connecting with the kitchen in the basement; and Holmes' desk, piled high with papers, clippings, research material, etc. Holmes is pulling up the window shades. Watson has removed his hat and coat, and is putting his medical bag down on the sideboard; the cabbie, having deposited their luggage, is just leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do wish you'd give me a little more warning when you come home unexpected.    I would have roasted a goose -- and had some flowers for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Mrs. Hudson -- criminals are as unpredictable as head-colds. You never quite know when you're going to catch one. He has picked up a dagger, starts opening his mail, which is on the dining table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll unpack your bags. She exits into one of the bedrooms.   Watson has now take a magazine out of an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's an advance copy of Strand Magazine. (shows it to Holmes) They've printed 'The Red-Headed League!' On the cover is a colored illustration from the story, featuring in obligatory Inverness and deerstalker.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (offhand) Very impressive.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: (leafing through the magazine) Would you like to see how I treated it?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I can hardly wait. I'm sure I'll find out all sorts of fascinating things about the case that I never knew before.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: Just what do you mean by that?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Oh, come now, Watson, you must admit that you have a tendency to over-romanticize. You have taken my simple exercises in logic and embellished them, exaggerated them...

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: I deny the accusation.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: You have described me as six-foot-four, whereas I am barely six-foot-one.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: A bit of poetic license.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (removing Inverness and deerstalker) You have saddled me with this improbable costume, which the public now expects me to wear.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: That's not my doing. (indicating cover of Strand) Blame it on the illustrator.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: You've made me out to be a violin virtuoso. Here --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds out a letter he's been reading) -- a request from the Liverpool Symphony to appear as soloist in the Mendelssohn Concerto.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: (excited) Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: The fact is that I could barely hold my own in the pit orchestra of a second-rate music hall.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: You're much too modest.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (busy with the mail) You have given the reader the distinct impression that I am a misogynist. Actually, I don't dislike women -- I merely distrust them. The twinkle in the eye and the arsenic in the soup.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: It's those little touches that make you colorful --

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Lurid is more like it. You have painted me as a hopeless dope addict -- just because I occasionally take a five per cent solution of cocaine.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: A seven per cent solution.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Five per cent. Don't you think I'm aware you've been diluting it behind my back?

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: As a doctor -- and as your friend -- I strongly disapprove of this insidious habit of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear friend -- as well as my dear doctor -- I only resort to narcotics when I am suffering from acute boredom -- when there are no interesting cases to engage my mind. (holding out one of the open letters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this -- an urgent appeal to find six missing midgets. He tosses the letter down is disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say midgets? He picks up the letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six of them -- the Tumbling Piccolos -- an acrobatic act with some circus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappeared between London and Bristol ... Don't you find that intriguing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extremely so. You see, they are not only midgets -- but also anarchists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anarchists?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) By now they have been smuggled to Vienna, dressed as little girls in burgundy pinafores. They are to greet the Czar of all the Russias when he arrives at the railway station. They will be carrying bouquets of flowers, concealed in each bouquet will be a bomb with a lit fuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. The circus owner offers me five pounds for my services -- that's not even a pound a midget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So obviously he is a stingy blighter, and the little chaps simply ran off to join another circus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crestfallen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.    And it sounded so promising --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no great crimes anymore, Watson. The criminal class has lost all enterprise and originality. At best they commit some bungling villainy, with a motive so transparent that even a Scotland Yard official can see through it. He has crossed to the desk, suddenly notices something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) Mrs. Hudson! (even angrier)

dialogues.speaker: MRS. HUDSON
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hudson comes hurrying out of the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?    What is it? What have I done now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly) There is something missing from my desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something very crucial. (picks up a small feather) You have been tidying up against my explicit orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I made sure not to disturb anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dust, Mrs. Hudson, is an essential part of my filing system. By the thickness of it, I can date any document immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the dust was this thick. She demonstrates with her thumb and forefinger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (promptly) That would be March, 1883. He blows the feather away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: START on Holmes' foot, operating a bellows. CAMERA PANS UP to the top of the chemistry table, on which an elaborate apparatus of brass, glass and rubber tubing has been set up. Inserted into the ends of the rubber tubes are half a dozen cigarettes, four cigars of different shapes and colors, and four pipes, all lit. Activated by the bellows, they are puffing away like mad, wheezing loudly and filling the screen with smoke. Seated at the table is Holmes, in shirt-sleeves. Occasionally he knocks off an ash onto a glass slide, studies it under a microscope. Watson, in a dressing gown, is sitting in the chair with the writing arm, documenting the latest Holmes adventure for Strand Magazine. The open mail has now been affixed to the center of the wooden mantelpiece, with a dagger. Mrs. Hudson is clearing the dinner dishes from the table, and loading them onto the shelf of the dumbwaiter. The accumulation of smoke in the room makes her cough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you stand this? Why don't you let me air the room out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mrs. Hudson -- he's working on a definitive study of tobacco ash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) I'm sure there's a crying need for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In our endeavors, it is sometimes vital to distinguish between, say, the ashes of a Macedonian cigarette and a Jamaican cigar. Sor far he has classified 140 different kinds of ashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of which will end up on my rug. She is now pulling on the rope which lowers the dumbwaiter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be enough, Mrs. Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heading for door) All right. If you gentlemen want to stay here and suffocate... She exits, shutting the door. For a while, the two go on working. Then Holmes rises abruptly from the chemistry table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's right.    I am suffocating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me open a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not from lack of air -- from lack of activity. Sitting here week after week -- blowing smoke rings -- staring through a microscope -- there's no challenge in that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally, I consider it a major contribution to scientific criminology... Holmes has opened his violin case and taken out his fiddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How I envy you your mind, Watson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's placid, imperturbable, prosaic. But my mind rebels against stagnation. It's like a racing engine, tearing itself to pieces because it's not connected up with the work for which it was built. He has tucked the violin under his chin, starts to improvise a nervous pent-up melody. There is nothing amateurish about it -- he plays quite well. Watson resumes working on his manuscript. Suddenly the music stops. Watson looks up apprehensively. Holmes has put down the violin, and is crossing to the sideboard. He opens Watson's medical bag, takes out a bottle of cocaine, starts toward his bedroom. Watson pushes the writing arm to the side, rises from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes -- Holmes   pays no   attention, continues into the bedroom. Watson   crosses   to the open door. Inside the bedroom, Holmes   has put   down the cocaine bottle on the washsta and is   rolling   up his left sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, where is your self-control?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair question. From a drawer he takes a morocco case, opens it, removes a hypodermic syringe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you ashamed of yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thoroughly.    But this will take care of it. He has removed the stopper from the cocaine bottle, and inserting the hypodermic needle into it, starts to draw up the liquid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is raining. A bus comes down the street, the open top deck sprouting umbrellas like black mushrooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally, I don't mean to imply that my friend was always on cocaine -- sometimes it was opium, sometimes it was hashish. And once he went one of these dreadful binges, there was no telling how long it would last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain beats on the windows.    Holmes and Watson are in th middle of an argument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only reason you moved in with me is to have a steady supply of stimulants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now, Watson -- you mustn't underestimate your other charms. He starts into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, I warn you. If you lock yourself in there once more --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I intend to do nothing of the sort. He takes the hypodermic out of the drawer in the washstand, starts back into the living room with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not until you replace this needle.    It is getting rather blunt. As Watson glares at him, the door opens and Mrs. Hudson comes bustling in. Holmes hides the hypodermic behind his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made you some tea and cress sandwiches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door of the dumbwaiter, starts to pull it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hudson, I want you to pack my bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going away for the weekend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And beyond.   I'm moving out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving out? (she looks at Holmes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just as surprised as you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard me, Mrs. Hudson.     And let's not waste any time. Mrs. Hudson sighs, exits into Watson's bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I be so bold as to ask where you'er going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know yet. But I intend to resume my practice. I am, after all, a doctor. And quite a competent one, if I say so as shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll find it very dull -- snipping out tonsils and flushing out kidneys -- Watson is glancing around the room, searching for something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're looking for your medical bag, you hid it under the Moorish table. (as Watson crosses to it) Which shows a little more imagination than last time -- when it was under your bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson picks up the Moorish table, disclosing the medical bag, standing on end. He sets the bag down on the fender, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, of course, continue to pay my half of the rent until you find someone to share these rooms with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I going to find anyone who will put up with my rather eccentric habits?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking hypodermic needle out of bag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a fresh needle -- and here's my farewell present to you. He takes out three bottles of narcotics, puts them on the mantel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to destroy yourself, go right ahead. But I won't sit by and watch you doing it. He snaps his bag shut, carries it toward his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson... Watson disappears into the bedroom, slamming the door. Holmes looks after him, then looks at the bottles of dope on the mantelpiece. He starts pacing. After a moment he stops at the chemistry table, studies the assorted glassware on the shelves above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are two open valises on the bed. Watson is moving around the room, collecting various odds and ends, while Mrs. Hudson packs his clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so sad. You and Mr. Holmes -- after all these years -- (she sobs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mrs. Hudson -- none of that. Mrs. Hudson takes a clean handkerchief from the open valise, blows her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wash this and send it on to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be at Brown's Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still sniffling) I know how it feels -- I once went through a divorce myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (removing diploma from wall) Actually, I'm rather looking forward to it. Leading a normal life again. Regular office hours -- nine to three -- and if occasionally there's an emergency call in the middle of the night, I know it's going be appendicitis and not an ax murder. Let Holmes go mucking about in the fog and the sleet, looking for a bloodstained collar-button out on the moors, with some demented hound snapping at his behind -- From the living room comes the sound of a revolver shot. Mrs. Hudson screams and Watson looks off in alarm. Then he races out of the room, diploma in hand, followed by Mrs. Hudson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they burst into the room, they see Holmes sitting on the stool beside the chemistry table, a revolver in his hand. He has shattered one of the narcotics bottles on the mantelpiece, and is aiming at a second one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Holmes... Holmes fires, smashing the second bottle. As Mrs. Hudson takes a step forward, he waves her away with the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mrs. Hudson.    You're in my line of fire. Watson jerks Mrs.   Hudson back as Holmes lets go with another shot. The    bullet disposes of the third bottle, splattering glass   and liquid all over the place. Holmes rises calmly from   the stool, crosses to the desk, puts the revolver away   in a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outraged) How many times have I told you I will not tolerate pistol practice on my premises? I should have evicted you when you shot them holes in my wall. She points up to a spot near the ceiling. Neatly traced in bullet holes are the initials V.R., with a small crown above them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merely celebrating Her Majesty's Golden Jubilee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that mess you made -- Watson is looking at Holmes with a little smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Mrs. Hudson. I'll clean it up -- (hands her the diploma) -- while you unpack my things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unpack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard him. A bewildered Mrs. Hudson goes back into the bedroom. Watson crosses to the fireplace, picks up the whiskbroom and the coal shovel, starts cleaning up the broken glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Holmes. I know how difficult it must've been for you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. It was simple choice between a bad habit and a good companion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've made me very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've often been accused of being cold and unemotional. I admit to it. And yet, in my cold, unemotional way, I'm very fond of you, Watson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that. But one likes to hear these things occasionally. He notices the violin, which has been splattered with the liquid from the shattered bottle, picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this. Covered with that nasty stuff. I'd better dry it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it. He takes the instrument, and dabbing it with a handkerchief, carries it toward the violin case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a moment, I was worried that you were going to let me walk out -- that you weren't even going to try to stop me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Watson -- you know there's nothing I wouldn't do to keep you here. With a side-glance at the busy Watson, he opens the violin case. Neatly stashed away around the edges are the three original bottles of narcotics. The ones he shot up, of course, were substitutes from the chemistry set. He places the violin carefully among the bottles, closes the case, snaps the locks. As he moves off, we STAY on the violin case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was not the first not the last time he tricked me like that. Normally, I was inclined to forgive him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson, in his dressing gown, is sitting at the table, finishing his coffee. In front of him is a letter, on blue note-paper, and a pair of theatre tickets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But on one occasion, he did something that was so utterly unforgivable, that I would gladly have murdered him -- had it not been for my saintly disposition. Watson sets down his coffee cup, picks up the letter and the tickets, rises from his chair. He starts to pace -- addressing Holmes, who is off-scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you being so stubborn, Holmes? Why won't you go? It's the final performance of the Imperial Russian Ballet -- the house has been sold out for months -- He moves towards the door of --

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES' BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Holmes is sitting in a hip-bath with a high back, soaping himself. Watson appears in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- seats are going for a guinea apiece --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's precisely it. Why should someone send up two free tickets? Anonymously, at that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever sent them must be in great distress. The note says --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading it) 'Please! You are the only man in the world who can help me.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suspect it's some sort of plot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean somebody wants to lure us into a trap...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody wants to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. It's a plot to bore me to death. I detest ballet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this isn't just any ballet.     It's Swan Lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: START ON THE CONDUCTOR, in the orchestra pit,   as he giv the downbeat for the second acto music of SWAN   LAKE. CAMERA PULLS BACK TO INCLUDE THE STAGE, with a   mechanic sway crossing the mist-shrouded lake. CAMERA    CONTINUES TO PULL BACK, REVEALING Holmes and Watson, in   evening clothes, occupying a box in the upper tier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confidentially) You know, of course, Holmes -- that swan isn't really a swan -- it's an enchanted princess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bored) H'mmmm. On the stage now, the hunters appear, carrying lighted torches.

dialogues.speaker: BOX
dialogues.text: Watson trains his opera glasses on the stage, Holmes stifles a yawn.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: PETROVA, as the Queen of the Swans, makes her entrance to loud applause. She is in her forties, but splendidly preserved, undoubtedly the greatest ballerina around.

dialogues.speaker: BOX
dialogues.text: Watson nudges Holmes, who has dozed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fabulous woman, don't you think so, Holmes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coming to) Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great Petrova. He hands the glasses to Holmes, who focuses them indifferently on the stage.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: Petrova is making an exit, backwards, on points.

dialogues.speaker: BOX
dialogues.text: Holmes lowers the glasses, returns them to Watson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very strong arches, I must admit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say twelve men have died for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six committed suicide, four were killed in duels, and one fell out of the gallery in the Vienna Opera House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's only eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man who fell from the gallery landed on top of another man in the orchestra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes an even dozen -- in a messy sort of way. Watson resumes watching the stage through the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: Petrova and the dancer playing the Prince go into the famous pas-de-deux.

dialogues.speaker: BOX
dialogues.text: Watson enjoying himself immensely, Holmes sitting there dourly. The red plush curtain at the rear of the box parts, and a man in evening clothes and a top hat enters. He is in his middle fifties, extremely soigne, and somewhat sinister. His name is ROGOZHIN, and he is Russian. Holmes and Watson look around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Holmes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am Nicolai Rogozhin, director-general of the Imperial Russian Ballet. So glad you accept invitation. Holmes and Watson start to get up, but he motions them back into their chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Dr. Watson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you. (seating himself behind them) You are enjoying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immensely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (abruptly) Tell me, Mr. Holmes, how is your health?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My health?   Better consult my doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rogozhin) Oh, he's in excellent shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Holmes) Any insanity in your family?   Diabetes? Asthma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind telling me what this is all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly.   Madame Petrova, she has problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you be more specific?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A liason with a crowned head? Compromising letters? Blackmail? He glances toward the stage.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: The pas-de-deux finished, to a rousing ovation.

dialogues.speaker: BOX
dialogues.text: Rogozhin rises, turns to Holmes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After performance, there will be little celebration backstage -- and Madame requests your presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd be delighted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Watson) You are invited, also. With a parting look he exits, pulling the plush curtains closed.

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: The performance is over, the curtain is up, the party is on. Tables have been set up, with caviar, vodka and champagne. The members of the orchestra are now playing balalaikas, and crew and cast (the ballerinas still in costume, the male dancers in tights) seem in high spirits. Holmes and Watson, in silk hats with canes, appear from the wings, stop, survey the scene. Watson's eyes are shining with anticipation. In contrast, Holmes' face is sober and quizzical. Rogozhin spots the two, detaches himself from a group, hurries over to join them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are, Mr. Holmes. Madame is expecting you in her dressing room. Dr. Watson, you will amuse yourself meanwhile -- we have vodka, caviar, girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No girls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No caviar. Makes me break out in hives. Rogozhin turns to a group of ballerinas, claps his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dievushki. Siude, siuda, dievushki. Posnakomtes s docktorum Watsonom. Half a dozen ballerinas descend on on Dr. Watson. They are giggling and chattering in Russian. Rogozhin leads Holmes off, while Watson takes in the bevy of beauties around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any of you girls understand English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nyet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not one single word?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nyet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that case, I don't mind telling you that you all have lovely po-pos. He pats a couple of the po-pos with his cane.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Rogozhin is leading Holmes toward Madame Petrova's dressing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Holmes, I must prepare you -- this is no ordinary case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is only the extraordinary that interests me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Because you will find this extra- extraordinary. They have now reached the door of Madame's dressing room. Rogozhin knocks. The door is opened by an elderly Russian maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Petrova prinimaet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pozhaluista voidite. Rogozhin leads Holmes inside.    The maid steps out, shut the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is small, elegant and sensuous. There is vodka in an ice-bucket, next to a Recamier chaise, a paravent, masses of flowers, and finally Madame Petrova, still in costume, sitting at a dressing table with multiple mirrors, undoing her hair. Candles, in two elaborate candleabra, give Madame's face a special glow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja priviol vam Mistera Sherlock Holmesa, doragaia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Holmes) Otchen rada. She extends her hand, and Holmes takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame. He kisses her hand. Petrova appraises him from head to toe, and back again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Holmes) Vi menshe rostom chem ja ozhidala.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame says you are shorter than she thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No eto nie vazhno. Menia interessujut glavnim obra som vashi mosghi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Short, tall, who cares?   It is the brains that count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rogozhin) Thank you. (catching himself, to Petrova)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Petrova rises, crosses to the paravent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ja prochia vsie vashi prikliuchenia. Zamiechatelno! Os sobenno sobaka Baskervillei.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame is great admirer of yours. She has read every story -- her favorite is Big Dog from Baskerville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it loses something in translation. Petrova is now behind the paravent, undressing, only her head visible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nikolai, pokazhite iemu skripku. Rogozhin picks up a violin case, opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Holmes, you know about fiddles. (takes violin out, hands it to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your opinion of this? Holmes holds the violin up, peers through one of the sound holes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) 'Antonius Stradivarius Cremonesis, Anno 1709.' Well, the label is authentic. (examines violin, plucks strings)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judging from the shape, the color of the varnish, and the tone, I would say it is a genuine Stradivarius of the best period.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's magnificent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from behind paravent) Skazhite jemu chto eto podarok ot menia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here -- take it. Madame says it is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For services you will render.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fees as a detective are not exactly trifling -- but a Stradivarius -- you're not serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am not.   But Madame is. Petrova emerges from behind the paravent, in a brocade dressing gown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nalejte vodki i obiasnite jemu v chom dielo. She drapes herself on the chaise.

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: All right.   I will pour vodka and explain. (starts pouring vodka; it is pink) Mr. Holmes, what you have seen tonight is last and positively final performance of Madame Petrova. She is retiring.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: What a shame.

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: She has been dancing since she was three years old. And after all, she is now thirty-eight.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: (gallantly) I must say she doesn't look thirty-eight.

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: That is because she is   forty-nine. (he hands her a   glass of vodka, with an   exaggerated smile) So Madame has decided   to leave ballet and spend life bringing up   her child.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: How admirable.

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: (hands him vodka) Problem now is to find father.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Oh?   Is he missing?

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: Correct.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: And that's why you called me in?

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: Also correct. We must have father, because without father, how can there be child?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. The whole thing is still in the planning stage --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Correct again. Madame would like child to be brilliant and beautiful. Since she is beautiful -- she now needs man who is brilliant. Holmes' eyes wander slowly toward Petrova.    She raises her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Za zdorovie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his glass) Za zdorovie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Za zdrovie. Petrova and Rogozhin down their vodka bottoms up.    Holm takes one swallow, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it taste like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red pepper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what's in it. While Rogozhin refills Petrova's glass and his own, Holmes takes another tentative sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Holmes) Kogda mi smozhem dvinutsa v putj?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: Madame wants to know how soon you can be ready.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: To leave for Venice. All arrangements have been made. You will spend one week there with Madame...

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Well, this is all very flattering. But surely there are other me -- better men --

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: To tell you truth, you were not first choice. We considered Russian writer, Tolstoi --

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: That's more like it.   The man's a genius.

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: Too old... Then we considered the philosopher, Nietzsche --

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Absolutely first-rate mind...

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: Too German... And we considered Tschaikowski --

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Oh, you couldn't go wrong with Tschaikowski --

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: We could -- and we did.   It was catastrophe.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: You don't know? Because Tschaikowski -- how shall put it? Women not his glass of tea.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Pity, that.

dialogues.speaker: PETROVA
dialogues.text: (to Rogozhin) Skazhite jemu chto je otchen dovolna etim resheniem.

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: Madame is very happy with final choice.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Madame mustn't be too hasty.   She must remember I'm an Englishman.

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: You know what they say about us. If there's one thing more deplorable than our cooking, it's our love-making. We are not exactly the most romantic of people --

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: Perfect. We don't want sentimental idiots -- falling in love, committing suicide. One week in Venice -- she goes back to St. Petersburg with baby -- you go back to London with fiddle.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: An equitable arrangement. (puts down violin) About my medical history -- when you asked me -- I neglected to mention a small detail. There is hemophilia in my family. We're all bleeders.

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: (to Petrova) On govorit, chto v jevo semie stradajut ghemofilijei.

dialogues.speaker: PETROVA
dialogues.text: Pust nie bezpokoitsa.    Ja ostrighu sebe noghti.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame says not to worry.    She will not scratch you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's reassuring to know.    But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rogozhin) Pochemu on kolebletsa? On nie nahodit menia dostatochno privlekatelnoi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame says you talk too much.    You find her attractive or no? Before Holmes can answer, the door opens and Watson sticks his head in. He is flushed and slightly inebriated, and there is a flower tucked behind his ear. From off comes the SOUND of wild balalaika music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. (to Rogozhin) What does prokanzik mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means 'You little devil.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does?   I am? Thank you. He hurries off, shutting the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Holmes) I repeat question. You find Madame attractive or no? Holmes is still looking at the door where Watson exited, an idea forming in his mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Rogozhin) Oh, I find her most attractive -- for a woman, that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then no problem.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Maybe a slight one.       You see, I am not a free man.

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: Not free?   You are a bachelor.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: A bachelor -- living with another bachelor -- for the last five years. Five very happy years.

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: What is it you are trying to tell me?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I hoped I could avoid the subject. But some of us -- through a cruel caprice of Mother Nature --

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: Get to point.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: The point is that Tschaikowski is not an isolated case.

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: You mean, you and Dr. Watson -- ? (Holmes nods) He is your glass of tea?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: If you want to be picturesque about it.

dialogues.speaker: PETROVA
dialogues.text: (slightly agitated) Chto on govorit? Pri chom tut Chaikovsky?

dialogues.speaker: ROGOZHIN
dialogues.text: On pederast.

dialogues.speaker: PETROVA
dialogues.text: (on her feet now; flaring) Jescho odin? Eto stanovitsa odnoobrasno! Kakoi vi idiot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking up his silk hat and cane)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, Madame, the loss is all mine. But I would prefer to disappoint you know than disappoint you in a gondola in Venice. He takes her limp hand, kisses it.   Then he crosses to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Rogozhin's accent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would have been catastrophe. He exits.   Rogozhin starts to pour himself another glass of vodka.   Petrova slaps the glass out of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Potchemu vi nie vijasnili eto eto ranshe, prezhde chem posoritj menia!

dialogues.speaker: STAGE
dialogues.text: The party has built into a real wingding by now. It's wild -- drinking, laughing, singing. Everybody is turned on -- especially Watson. He is dancing with a dozen of the ballerinas to madly accelerating balalaika music. Flower behind ear, hair mussed, tie undone, short of breath -- he is in paradise. Holmes makes his way through the revelers, approaches Watson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson! (Watson pays no attention)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson, are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without missing a step)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, old boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home? Not a chance. Not the slightest -- not the remotest chance. Toodle-ooo. He waves goodbye, and goes on swirling dizzily with the girls. Holmes puts on his silk hat and leaves. A shaken Rogozhin comes up to the buffet, pours himself a stiff drink of vodka. As he drinks his eyes follow the dancing Watson balefully. Watson spins off several of the girls, grabs another group. His ex-partners wind up close to Rogozhin. He whispers something to them. Their eyes widen, and they stare at Watson with disbelief. Watson again switches partners, and the first girls now whisper intensely to those who just left the floor. The same reaction. Watson, oblivious to all this, is whirling around with another set of girls. By now some of the girls who are in on the secret are whispering to the male dancers in tights. Their reaction is slightly different. They are seeing Watson in a new light. And before Watson knows what's happening, he has been abandoned by all the girls, and is joined first by one pair then another pair of male dancers, till he is dancing only with gay guys in tights. It gradually dawns on Watson that there is something wrong with this state of affairs. After some difficulty, he breaks away from them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on!    Just a moment! Spotting Rogozhin, he crosses to him.   The girls shrink away at his approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bewildered) What's going on? What happened to the girls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?   Do you not prefer it this way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to pretend. Mr. Holmes told us everything -- about you and him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About me and him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now, no need to be bashful. We are not bourgeois. Maybe with doctors and detectives is unusual -- but in ballet, is very usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Caprice of Mother Nature. Look at Pavel and Mischa and Boris and Dmitri -- Watson looks around at the boys in tights, who are standing in a half-circle, grinning at him insolently. It is beginning to dawn on him. He pales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- And Ilya and Sergei -- (breaks off, rocks his hand back and forth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergei -- half and half. He pours himself another vodka. Watson grabs the glass away from him, downs it with a gulp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In contrast to the frenetic ambiance of the back-stage party, the room seems doubly placid. Holmes, his dinner coat replaced by a smoking jacket, is sitting in the wing chair, having a quiet pipe after the evening's peculiar adventure. Only the desk lamp is lit. From the street, there is the sound of hurried, angry footsteps approaching the house. Holmes turns his head languidly -- he knows who is coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enraged Watson, cane and opera glasses in hand, and the flower still behind his ear, is jogging down the center of the deserted street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes rises casually, twists the wing chair so that its back is to the door, crosses to the lamp on the desk, turns the wick down. From off comes the sound of Watson's key rattling in the front door lock.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: The front door opens and Watson storms into the vestibule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes! He races up the stairs and across the landing, flings open the door of the flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson, grim and breathless, stands in the open doorway. Over the back of the wing chair, he sees smoke curling up from Holmes' pipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are, you wretch! You rotter! You blackguard! Of all the vile, unspeakable fabrications. What do you have to say for yourself? No answer from Holmes. We now see -- but Watson does not -- that the chair is occupied by a section of Holmes' smoking machine, with the pipe attached.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't just sit there -- speak up, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still no answer -- just a little pipe smoke drifting up from the wing chair. Incensed, Watson raises the opera glasses, tosses them toward the chair. There is a loud thud, the pipe falls to the floor, then there is silence. Watson suddenly becomes concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes...?   Are you all right, Holmes? He approaches the chair apprehensively, shoves  it aside and there on the floor is the smoking machine,  still wheezing slightly. Watson picks it up, and his   eyes travel to Holmes, standing in a shadowy corner,  working the bellows with his foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the sound of your footsteps, I gathered that you were not in a particularly amiable mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with renewed fury) How could you do a dastardly thing like that to me? What the deuce were you thinking of? He dashes the smoking machine to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson, you  have my most abject apologies.   But have you ever been cornered by  a madwoman?  It seemed like the only way  to get out of it without hurting her  feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about my feelings? And my reputation? Do you realize the gravity of what you have done? The possible repercussions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there'll be a little gossip about you in St. Petersburg...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These things spread like wildfire. I can just hear those malicious whispers behind my back. I'll never be able to show my face in polite society...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if it ever got back to my old regiment -- you don't know the Fifth Northumberland Fusiliers -- they'll strike me off the rolls -- they'll cut off my pension...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson, you're running amok.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dishonored, disgraced, ostracized.   What am I to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for one thing, I'd get rid of that flower. He points to the flower behind Watson's ear. Watson grabs the flower, hurls it into the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may think this is funny, but we're both in the same boat. We must take desperate measures. We must stop this talk... (a beat, then an idea) Maybe if we got married...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then they'd really talk...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starts pacing) Obviously, we cannot continue to live under the same roof. We must move apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, we can still see each other clandestinely -- on remote benches in Hyde Park, and in the waiting rooms of suburban railway stations --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a change in attitude; defiant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole thing is ridiculous.   We have nothing to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I've been trying to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let somebody start a rumor -- just one ugly word -- and we'll sue them for slander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody would dare. After all, you have an enviable record with the fair sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right. I can get women from three continents to testify for me. And you can get women to vouch for you, too -- can't you, Holmes? No answer from Holmes.   Watson is becoming a little concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you, Holmes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Watson. He starts toward his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, let me ask you a question -- (Holmes stops) I hope I'm not being presumptuous -- but there have been women in your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The answer is yes. (a relieved sigh from Watson) You're being presumptuous. (Watson's face falls) Good night. He walks into his bedroom, shutting the door.    Watson takes a tentative step after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a cheery fire burning in the grate. Holmes is stretched out full-length on the couch, playing a set of Corelli variations on his violin. Watson is in his usual chair, reading the Evening Standard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, indeed, was his attitude toward women? Was there some secret he was holding back -- or was he just a thinking machine, incapable of any emotion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wisps of fog swirl along the street, making yellow haloes around street lamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was not to get the answer until we became involved in what I consider to be the most outrageous case in all our years together. Out of the mist comes a hansom cab, with the dim figure of a woman visible in the passenger seat. The cab stops in front of 221B, and the driver starts to get down. From upstairs comes the faint sound of violin music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson steps up to the window, pulls the curtain aside, looks down toward the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cabbie crosses the pavement, consults an address in his hand, glances up at the number of the house, then rings the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson turns away from the window, as the BELL downstairs rings again. Holmes stops playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you expecting someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at this hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Mrs. Hudson is entertaining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never found her so. Watson crosses to the door, opens it, steps out.   Holmes resumes playing Corelli.

dialogues.speaker: VESTIBULE AND STAIRCASE
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hudson, in a robe and night-cap, is talking to the cabbie in the open street door when Watson appears on the landing above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Mrs. Hudson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) There's a cabbie here -- he says you owe him two-and-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Watson) For the fare, guv'nor. The young lady doesn't have any money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What young lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one. He reaches out the door, pulls in the young lady in question. She is in her early thirties, with strikingly handsome features, but at the moment she is somewhat worse for wear. She is wrapped in a blanket, her hair is wet, and there is a bruise on her temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is wearing and wedding ring and her name, we will subsequently learn, is GABRIELLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  What have we here? (he starts down the stairs) Who are you, miss? What happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slight accent) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all she keeps saying -- I don't know, I don't know. The violin music stops o.s.   Watson has now reached the foot of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did she come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the river. I was driving down the Embankment, just below Westminster Bridge, and there she was in the water -- drowning. Holmes appears on the landing above, violin and bow in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't easy, guv'nor -- what with the cold water -- and her fighting me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the upper landing) Why did you bring her here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I found this in her hand -- (gives a square of soggy cardboard to Watson)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- 221B Baker Street -- that's right, isn't it? Watson examines the cardboard, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gabrielle) Young lady -- what did you want at this address?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up, trying to focus) I do not remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Holmes) Rather perplexing, wouldn't you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, gentlemen, you want her? -- it's two-and-six -- or shall I throw her back in the river?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Holmes.   You can't let him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson, you'd better accept delivery. Watson fishes some coins out of his pocket, hands them to the cabbie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep the change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, guv'nor. He snatches the blanket off Gabrielle, revealing that her dress is clinging to her damply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No extra charge for the use of the horse- blanket. He exits into the street, shutting the door.    Gabrielle hugs herself for warmth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're shivering, my dear. (he puts his arm around her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come along. Let me get you out of those wet clothes. He starts to lead her up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cabbie has tossed the blanket into the hansom, and is mounting the driver's seat. Across the street, a man steps out of the fog into a pool of light cast by one of the street lamps. He is a craggy-faced Prussian of about fifty, and his name is VON TIRPITZ. He looks up toward the Holmes flat. As the hansom makes a U-turn and comes abreast of him, he hops into the cab. The hansom disappears into the fog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson is leading Gabrielle to a chair by the fireplace. Holmes is putting his violin down on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit here, my dear. He settles her in the chair. Holmes comes over, plucks the square of cardboard from Watson's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's suffering from shock and exposure. He starts to massage her wrists to restore her circulation. Holmes is examining the soggy cardboard. On one side is their address, written in pencil. He turns it over, disclosing some smudges of green ink on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was some printing on the back of this -- but it seems to have come off in the water. Watson is now studying the bruise on Gabrielle's temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at this -- she's had a nasty blow on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could she have hit her head when she fell or jumped into the river?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The blood has already coagulated. So it would appear that she was the victim of a deliberate attack... Get my bag, will you? As Holmes fetches the medical bag, Gabrielle looks from one to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Dr. Watson -- and this is Mr. Sherlock Holmes. Do the names mean anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you think of your own name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat, then shakes her head)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's obviously had a concussion -- which often leads to temporary amnesia. He has now taken some cotton and a bottle of antiseptic out of the medical bag, and is swabbing her wound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So all we know is that she was coshed on the head, dumped into the Thames, and subsequently dumped into our laps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know a lot more than that. From her accent, we know she is foreign -- from her ring, we know she is married -- and there is one other clue we have... Something I deduced while I was helping her up the stairs. No corset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good work. He glances down at Gabrielle's shoe, which has slipped off her foot. Inside, slightly worn away, are the words: LA FEMME ELEGANTE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gabrielle) Are you French? (in Berlitz French) Vous etes Francaise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concentrating -- then) Non, je ne suis pas Francaise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can she say she's not French, in French?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vous etes Suisse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Non.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alors, vous etes Belge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (haltingly) Je suis pas sure. Holmes reaches behind her, turns back the collar of her dress. Sewn inside is a label reading: BAZAAR MODERN, Bruxelles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vous etes Belge -- de Bruxelles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bruxelles?    Oui... Je pense que oui. Mrs. Hudson has come in with a loaded tea-tray, starts to put it down on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, dash. Will someone remove the violin, please? Watson takes the violin off the table, and she sets down the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just found out that she's Belgian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poor thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Brussels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking Gabrielle's hand) If you don't mind. He slips the wedding ring off her finger, picks up a magnifying glass, examines it. It is made of copper, and engraved on the inside is the inscription: Gabrielle - Emile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name is Gabrielle, is that right? Gabrielle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your husband's name is Emile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely) Emile... HOLMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he? What are you doing in London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you arrive from Brussels?     Where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened at the river?   Think! Pensez! Concentrez vous! Gabrielle bursts into sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping forward) That's enough, Holmes. I will not permit you to question her in this condition. (helps the sobbing Gabrielle out of the chair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hudson, put her to bed. My bed. (Mrs. Hudson gives him a look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll sleep on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, my dear. She puts her arm around Gabrielle, who is still crying, leads her into Watson's bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd better mix her a sleeping potion. He gets a packet of white powder out of his medical bag, and during the following, stirs a spoonful into her tea- cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson, I think we should arrange to have her removed to a hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under no circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She should have medical attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can get that from me. But more importantly, she must be protected -- there has already been one attempt on her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This temporary amnesia -- how temporary is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It depends on the extent of the injury. It's like veils shrouding her memory. It could clear up in a few days -- or a few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson, this is a very small flat -- we don't want to clutter it up with women...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, we've never had a case like this. A woman comes to us with a problem -- we don't know who the woman is -- and we don't know what the problem is. Don't you find that challenging?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite. But we can't afford to wait for those veils to lift -- we must break through them as quickly as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You   really feel it's that urgent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. The sooner we solve the case, the sooner we can get rid of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. He picks up the cup of tea with the sedative in it, carries it toward the door of his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street lamps are still lit. A policeman, on patrol duty, is strolling along the sidewalk, swinging his truncheon. Suddenly he sees something up ahead. Alarmed, he ducks into the doorway of a building, flattens himself against the door. From the opposite direction comes a horse-drawn water- sprinkling wagon. The spray covers the sidewalks as well as the street. The policeman waits till the wagon is past, then steps out of the doorway relieved, resumes his patrol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson is asleep on the couch, covered with a blanket. He doesn't look as if he were in a very comfortable position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, in a dressing gown, is standing by the window, studying the square of cardboard with the green smudges on it. His bed has not been slept in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle is asleep in Watson's bed. The door opens slowly, and Holmes looks in. He studies the sleeping Gabrielle for a moment, then quietly pulls the door shut. As the latch clicks into place, Gabrielle awakes and sits up in bed, her back to CAMERA. She is nude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emile? She starts to get out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes is back in his room, once more examining the cardboard by the light of the window. The door of Watson's bedroom opens, and Gabrielle comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emile? Holmes looks up as Gabrielle appears in the open doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emile?   Is that you, Emile?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping into shadow) Yes, Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hurrying toward him) Ah, Emile. I thought I'd never find you. (embracing him) Hold me. Hold me tight. (Holmes puts his arms around her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been such a long time. So many nights. You know what I did before I left Brussels?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you won't be angry with me. I bought myself an expensive negligee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving toward bed) A pink negligee with maribou feathers. Don't you think that's a foolish thing for a married woman? (she gets into bed, beckons to him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is the negligee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my luggage... Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving toward her) And where is your luggage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatiently) I don't know. Come, my love.   Come. Please. As she extends her right hand to him, in a beckoning gesture, Holmes notices something on the palm. He takes her hand in his. There, in the same green ink as the smudges on the cardboard, are what appear the be the letters "I", "O", and Greek "E". Crossing to the wash- stand, he picks up his magnifying shaving mirror, returns to the bed, holds it up against the palm of Gabrielle's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Emile? What are you doing? Clearly reflected in the mirror is the reverse image of the lettering on Gabrielle's palm -- the number "301".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table is set for breakfast, and Mrs. Hudson is opening the curtains, flooding the room with sunlight. Then she moves over to the couch, where Watson is sleeping in an awkward position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Watson! (she claps her hands and he wakes up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your porridge is getting lumpy. Hadn't you better get up? Watson tries to rise, falls back with a moan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to very much. But -- (he turns over on his stomach)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hudson, would you mind planting your knee in the small of my back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please!   I'm in excruciating pain. Mrs. Hudson tentatively rests her knee on Watson's back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit higher -- just below my seventh vertebra -- (Mrs. Hudson follows instructions)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good. Put your arms under mine -- fold them behind my neck -- Mrs. Hudson presses down harder, and there is a distinct snap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless you. (he rises, rubbing his neck) That damn couch. (crossing to table) You'd better see if our patient is awake. He seats himself at the table. Mrs. Hudson crosses to the door of Watson's bedroom, opens it, starts inside, then stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Watson.   She's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone? He jumps up from the table, joins Mrs. Hudson, looks past her. The bed is empty. Gabrielle's clothes are in evidence, but there is no sign of her. Watson strides towards Holmes' bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes!   Holmes! She's gone! He throws the door open, is about to step inside when he sees something that makes him freeze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle is asleep in Holmes' bed, covered by just a sheet, and obviously naked underneath. Holmes is not in the room. Mrs. Hudson comes up behind Watson, in the open doorway, peers over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scandalized) Well, I never! There is the sound of the hall door opening, and they both turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes breezes in, carrying a large suitcase, with leather straps around it. Tucked under the straps is a white parasol. And attached to the handle of the suitcase is a cardboard tag with the number 301 on it, in green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inhaling deeply) Mmmmm. I smell porridge.   Lumpy as usual, I suppose. He sets the suitcase down on the couch, as Watson and Mrs. Hudson approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there you are, Holmes. We were just wondering -- how -- (points from his bedroom to Holmes')

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly) We certainly were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hudson, why don't you go down to the kitchen -- get a towel -- and wipe that look of disapproval off your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liberties -- in my house! She exits huffily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't really blame her -- I mean, the way it looks -- if I didn't know you better, I might suspect you'd taken advantage of the young lady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I did take advantage of her... Would you hand me the butter- knife, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. He picks up the butter-knife from the table, suddenly turns back with a delayed reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking butter-knife from him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He starts to pry open the locks of the suitcase with the butter-knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spluttering) Holmes, this is reprehensible! Where are your professional ethics? Have you no sense of decency, no shame --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None whatsoever. If you must know, I found her body quite rewarding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Especially the palm of her right hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather not hear about it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. Then I won't bother to tell you how I traced her suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's her suitcase?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember that piece of soggy cardboard with our address on it? It was a luggage ticket -- the number rubbed off on her hand. And since she must have arrived from Brussels by the boat train, I concluded that she had checked her belongings at Victoria Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By Jove! If you're right, we should find a clue to her identity. Holmes has now forced open the locks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or at least a pink negligee with maribou feathers. He opens the suitcase, lifts out the top piece of clothing, holds it up -- a pink negligee with maribou feathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Voila!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see - what else is in here? They start sorting through the clothes in the suitcase. Holmes removes a tied bundle of letters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we're getting somewhere. As he examines the envelope, Watson takes out a framed photo of a rather attractive man of fifty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do you suppose this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle appears from Holmes' bedroom wearing Holmes' dressing gown. She is unsteady on her feet and somewhat dazed. Holmes looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, Madame Valladon. (Gabrielle stops) You are Gabrielle Valladon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up photo) And this is your husband, Emile Valladon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Her eyes fall on the open suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to have ransacked your valise.     But since you came to us for help --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 221B Baker Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes... (a beat, as she orients herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which of you is Mr. Holmes and which is Dr. Watson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Watson is the handsome one. Watson, pleased, twirls the end of his mustache. Gabrielle sways slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way he affects most women. He helps her into a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gabrielle) Coffee. You want strong coffee. He hurries over to the breakfast table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all so confusing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's try to sort it out. You came to London looking for your husband...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. He's a mining engineer. We were married five years ago, in the Congo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where your husband was working in a copper mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wedding ring -- it's made of copper. He picks it up from the chemistry table, hands it to her. Gabrielle starts to put it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last year he invented a new kind of air pump, and was hired by an English company, Jonah Limited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing her cup of of coffee)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah Limited. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been writing to each other regularly. Then suddenly,  three weeks ago, his letters stopped.  I kept writing ... but no answer. Finally  I decided to go to that address --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
