dialogues.text: She indicates the bundle of letters. Holmes glances at the return address on the back of the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 Ashdown Street. GABRIELLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's just an empty store -- nobody there. Then I tried to find Jonah Limited. No such company exists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How decidedly odd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Valladon, can you think of any reason why your husband should have lied to you about theses things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emile?   Never. He loves me -- and I love him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I gathered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to the police -- they said they would send out a missing persons report -- but they didn't sound too encouraging. Then I went to the Belgian embassy and explained the situation to them -- and they suggested that I consult you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could have done worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was on my way here -- and suddenly there were footsteps behind me -- and a hand over my mouth -- and the smell of choloroform -- and the next thing I knew I was in the water -- and then a man was wrapping me in a blanket --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Valladon, somebody tried to kill you last night. Do you have any idea who could have done it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand any of it. (rises, goes to Holmes) What does it all mean, Mr. Holmes? Where is my husband? You must help me find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll do our best, I assure you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Valladon, I want you to send one more letter to your husband. He crosses to the desk, picks up a sheet of paper and an envelope, then leads Gabrielle over to the chair with the writing arm, seats her in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Emile Valladon -- Ashdown Street -- what was that number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (addressing envelope) 32. What do you want me to say in the letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. He folds the blank sheet of paper, and as Gabrielle finishes addressing the envelope, he inserts the paper in it, starts to seal it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sending an empty sheet of paper to an empty shop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That empty shop is obviously    being used as an accomodation address,    or letter- drop. But what gets dropped     must be picked up. The question is     how? -- and by whom? -- and why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a run-down district in the northwestern part of London. On the corner is No. 32 -- a dilapidated abandoned shop, with windows painted halfway up. As CAMERA APPROACHES the building, we hear sawing from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is dusty, cobwebby, quite forbidding. In the rear wall is a closed sliding door, indented about a foot into the shop. Nearby stands a large, square object, covered with a tarpaulin. High up in the rear wall is a slanted skylight, fitted with an iron grill. From outside, Holmes, in deerstalker and Inverness, can be seen sawing through the iron bars. Watson and Gabrielle are beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hammer... Chisel. Watson hands him the indicated tools. Holmes chips away the cement from the top and bottom of the last bar, then using it as a hinge, swings the grill open. He lets himself through the skylight, drops to the floor. Watson now helps Gabrielle through the skylight, lowers her toward Holmes, who puts his arms around her waist, eases her to the floor. For a brief moment he keeps his arms around her. Watson has now squeezed through the skylight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here! He hands the tools to Holmes, jumps to the floor. Gabrielle is looking around the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so strange to think I've been writing to a place like this all these months. Watson crosses to the square tarpaulin-covered object. He lifts up one corner of the tarp -- and is greeted by a loud twittering of birds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What he has uncovered is a large cage -- and about a hundred canaries, suddenly disturbed, are flapping around unside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at all these canaries. Do you suppose this could have been a pet shop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. (pointing off) Here comes our letter. Through the front window, the silhouette of a postman can be seen approaching. He drops a letter through the slot in the front door, moves on. The letter lands on a section of floor which is solidly covered with dust -- except for a series of double tracks, running to the door and curving back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we are faced with the most nerve- wracking part of the detective's job -- doing nothing. He reassembles the three tools, fitting each section into another, to form a cane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Holmes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how I'm going to pay you for all this. The purse with my money is somewhere at the bottom of the Thames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be worse. You could be at the bottom of the Thames -- much to your discomfort -- and much to my chagrin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand how anybody picks up letters here. (pointing) No footprints -- just tracks. What does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would surmise somebody is using ice- skates -- if it weren't for a conspicuous absence of ice. They become aware of a squeaking noise outside the rear of the shop, growing louder as it gets nearer. The noise stops, there is the sound of a lock turning, then the rattle of a chain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a frantic whisper) What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unfazed) This way. He leads Gabrielle and Watson toward the rear wall, right next to the door. They flatten themselves with their backs to the wall, just as the door slides open -- concealing them from view. Revealed is the mews behind the shop. In the door is an old BIDDY with straggly hair, sitting in a wheelchair. In her lap are a bulky paper bag and a tin pitcher filled with water. As she wheels herself inside, the unoiled wheelchair squeaks loudly. She stops in front of the cage, pulls on a rope which runs through a pulley in the ceiling -- and the tarpaulin rises into the air, exposing the canaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (addressing birds) Good morning, my pretties. Here's Mum with your breakfast. Did you think I'd forgotten you? She pours grain from the paper bag into a feeder hanging inside the cage, pours water from the pitcher into a trough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some  of you will be going on a little trip  soon -- I hate to lose you -- but even  an old woman has to live. Although you  might well ask, why? She cackles to herself, glances toward the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.   You never told me we had a letter. She starts to wheel herself toward the front of the shop. Through a crack in the door behind which our three are hiding, we see Holmes' eye watching her. The old woman reaches the letter, picks it up, studies the address. Then she hears something, glances toward the open rear door. A horse-drawn wagon with a canvas top is just pulling into the mews. Two CARTERS jump down from the driver's seat, and one of them takes a small bird-cage from the back of the wagon. As they start in through the door, the old woman drops the letter into her lap, wheels herself toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Duchess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you been doing with yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? Taking dancing lessons. (she stops in front of the cage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many do you want this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two dozen. He opens the door of the small cage, the bottom of which is covered with newspaper, starts transferring canaries into it from the large cage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they doing with all those canaries? What's going on up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Duchess, we don't know -- and we don't want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you work for Jonah, it's better not to ask questions. Through the crack in the door behind which he is hidden, we see Holmes' eye studying the small bird cage, as the canaries are being transferred into it. We MOVE IN CLOSE on the small cage, and see the soiled newspaper spread on the bottom. The masthead reads: INVERNESS COURIER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (counting as he transfers canaries)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... twenty-two, twenty-three, twenty- four. He closes the doors of the cages, picks up the small cage. His companion indicates the letter in the woman's lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about that letter? Does that go, too? WOMAN IN WHEELCHAIR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's going to be picked up in person. She chuckles. The carriers exit into the mews, stash the cage in the back of the wagon, mount the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to birds) All right, my pretties. Back to sleep you go. See you tomorrow. She pulls the rope and the tarpaulin drops back over the cage. Then she deposits the letter on top of the covered cage, wheels herself out the rear door. As she slides it shut from outside, our trio is revealed in their hiding places behind the door. There is the sound of the chain rattling, the lock snapping, and the squeaky wheels moving off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a sigh of relief) I really thought we were done for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (casually) The art of concealment, my dear Watson, is merely a matter of being in the right place at the right time. They step forward, and through the painted shop window watch the old woman wheel herself down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear what she said? You really think Emile is going to pick up the letter himself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It certainly would simplify things, wouldn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Maildrops and canaries and wheelchairs... And what was all that about Jonah? And what do you suppose they're doing up there? And where is up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My guess would be Scotland.   Inverness, to be more precise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inverness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you notice the paper at the bottom of their cage? The Inverness Courier. Gabrielle glances casually at the letter the old woman left lying on top of the cage, and her expression changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Holmes! This letter -- (she picks it up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding it out to him) It's addressed to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes takes the letter, examines the envelope.    It is indeed addressed to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevertheless -- With the saw-end of his cane, he slits the envelope open, removes the enclosure, unfolds it. We see the letter in his hand as he reads it out loud. The letterhead says: DIOGENES CLUB, St. James's, London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Dear Sherlock: I expect you and Dr. Watson to join me at the club immediately upon reciept of this note. According to my calculations, that should be at 11:40 a.m. Your brother, Mycroft. (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time do you make it, Watson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (consulting watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either your watch is wrong, or Mycroft has miscalculated. And knowing Mycroft, I suggest you reset your watch. Watson automatcially obeys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, cane in hand, and Watson are swiftly ascending the steps of a building with an imposing Palladian facade. Beside the entrance is a discreet sign reading: DIOGENES CLUB. Members Only. As they reach the top of the steps, Watson stops Holmes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind telling you I'm a bit apprehensive about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm rather curious myself as to what is going on in that Machiavellian mind of his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean Mycroft, I mean Madame Valladon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.    She's perfectly safe with Mrs. Hudson. He opens the door and they start in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dominating the lobby is a large statue of Queen Victoria. Presiding over the reception desk is a uniformed PORTER of military bearing, with one arm and a chest full of campaign ribbons. Holmes and Watson stride in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to porter) To see Mr. Mycroft Holmes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right you are. He's expecting you in the upstairs study. Now if you gentlemen will sign in -- (opens leather-bound register, turns it toward them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surname, Christian name, address, nature of business -- He holds out the pen to them, but they are gone. He looks around in consternation, sees them hurrying up the majestic staircase, steps out from behind his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen...!

dialogues.speaker: READING ROOM
dialogues.text: A huge room, with more marble than a mausoleum, and just about as lively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen elderly Establishment types are sunk deep in the leather armchairs, buried behind their copies of The Times.  Holmes and Watson are proceeding toward the study.  Suddenly Holmes stops beside one of the old fossils, who has fallen asleep in his chair, The Times in his lap, and between his fingers a lighted cigar with an ash four inches long. Holmes picks up an ashtray, holds it under the cigar -- just in time to catch the falling ash. As  he replaces the ashtray, he scrutinizes the ash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jamaican, no doubt -- either Tropical or Golosina -- I'm not quite sure. He and Watson continue toward the study door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a very elegant room   -- shelves of leather-bound volumes reach to the high   ceiling, there are antique terrestrial and celestial   gloves, scientific instrument in polished brass, marble   busts of English statesmen. MYCROFT HOLMES is standing at a refectory table, with his back to the door, engaged in a curious operation. A dusty bottle of wine is held in an ingeniously engineered cradle. As he turns the crank, the bottle tilts forward gently, and he decants the wine into three glasses without disturbing the sediment. Mycroft is an impressive figure of a man, seven years older than Sherlock, impeccably dressed. Behind his snobbish airs and bantering manner, one senses tremendous reserves of strength and authority. The door opens, and Holmes and Watson enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without turning)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, come in, Sherlock -- Dr. Watson... Sit down. (Holmes and Watson seat themselves)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking very fit, both of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting down hat and cane) And how are you, Mycroft? How's your gout?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under control. Except for the occasional twinge. He brings over two of the glasses of wine to Holmes and Watson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a treat for you -- a very old Madeira -- 1814. There are  only six bottles left in the world.  I have two of them, and am negotiating for a third.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind my saying so, anybody who's susceptible to gout shouldn't be -- Mycroft has moved back to the table and picked up his glass of Madeira.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last doctor who warned me about that was crossing Piccadilly, slipped on an orange peel, and was run over by a delivery van from the Fortnum and Mason. Your very good health. He and Watson sip their drinks, but not Holmes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you wasting this precious stuff on us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I see you so rarely. How long has it been? Not since the case of the Greek interpreter. (to Watson) Isn't it ridiculous? Two brothers living in the same town...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the same town, perhaps -- but not the same world.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: (taking another sip) Mmmm.    Superb. How old did you say it was?

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: 1814.    One year before Waterloo.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: One year before Waterloo?    Think of that.

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: You do know where Waterloo is, don't you, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: Belgium, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: Quite. (turning to Holmes) And speaking of Belgium, it has come to my attention that you are interested in the whereabouts of a certain engineer.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Yes, I am.

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: Well, I can save you a lot of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I'd be grateful for any suggestion --

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: My suggestion is that you pursue it no further.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Any particular reason?

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: Because it involves the national security. We are handling this matter ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: We?   Who's we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Diogenes Club, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have always suspected that there was some underground connection between this stodgy and seemingly calcified establishment and the Foreign Office in Whitehall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's neither here nor there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to me that The Diogenes Club is here, there and everywhere. When there are rumblings of revolt in the Sudan, an expedition subsidized by your club conveniently shows up to study the source of the Nile. When there is trouble along the Indian frontier, some of your fellow members pop up in the Himalayas, alledgedly looking for the Abominable Snowman. A YOUNG MAN in morning coat and striped trousers comes in, holding a telegram. Mycroft crosses to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Watson) What a fertile imagination my brother has. At the age of five, by carefully observing a neighbor's house, he deduced that babies were brought not by the stork, but by the mid-wife in her satchel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As good an explanation as any. Mycroft has taken the telegram, and is coming forward with it. The young man clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Wiggins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An immediate answer is requested, sir. Mycroft inserts a monocle in his eye, opens the telegram, moves toward the desk reading it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell them that the three boxes go to Glennahurich, and the red runner goes to the castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three boxes to Glennahurich, the red runner to the castle. Very good, sir. He exits. Holmes glances toward the telegram as Mycroft puts it down on his desk. Catching his look, Mycroft turns his telegram face-down, lets the monocle drop from his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you crumple it up and swallow it -- to make sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Sherlock, there  are certain affairs that do not come  within the province of the private  detective. They have to be dealt with on  an altogether different level.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In other words, you want me to stay within my limits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking of limits, what exactly is Jonah Limited?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherlock, when I said drop this case, it was not merely a suggestion -- it was an order!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By whose authority?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the authority of Her Majesty's government. I hope I've made myself clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly. In his nervousness he drops his bowler, which rolls along the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now if you'll excuse me, gentlemen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pleasure, as always. He and Watson retrieve their hats, move toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Holmes) Just a minute. (picks up Holmes' cane) You forgot your tool-kit. He tosses the cane to Holmes, who catches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes and Watson are walking toward 221B.   Holmes is whistling 'Loch Lomond.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be gentle, won't you, when you tell her you're dropping the case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson, what does the word Glennahurich suggest to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Scottish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And like all Scottish names, it's really a word picture. Glen means valley, na means of the, and Hurich, if memory serves me, means yew tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just trying to impress me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the three boxes go to the Valley of the Yew Tree. He resumes whistling. They start to cross the street, skirting a parked hansom. Feeding the horse is the same cabbie who fished Gabrielle out of the river, and in the passenger seat is Von Tirpitz, the craggy-faced Prussian we saw before. He stares fixedly after Holmes and Watson. Holmes and Watson come up to the door of 221B, and Watson fishes his key out. Holmes is still whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing along) And I'll be in Scotland before ye... (breaks off, looks at Holmes apprehensively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are dropping the case, aren't you, Holmes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the door. Watson turns the key in the lock, starts to open the door, but is stopped by a chain on the inside. Through the opening a revolver appears, aiming at them point- blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shoot, Mrs. Hudson -- you're liable to lose two excellent tenants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Hudson withdraws the gun, unhooks the chain. She is also holding an embroidery hoop. She opens the door, and Holmes and Watson step into the vestibule. MRS. HUDSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, at last. It's been a ghastly experience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?   What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever try doing embroidery with a gun in your hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking gun from her) You'll be relieved to know it was not loaded. He starts up the stairs, followed by Watson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, you didn't answer my  question. Are you planning to disobey  Mycroft's orders? He's not just your   brother, you know. You'd be defying Her   Majesty's government... No reaction from Holmes. As they reach the landing, Gabrielle is waiting for them in the open doorway of their flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any news?   Did you find out anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes and Watson step inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just say I know what the next step will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (anxious) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to pack your things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, let me caution you --- Holmes has put the gun down, and is crossing to one of the book-shelves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gabrielle) At 7:30 this evening, Dr. Watson and I are going to take you to Victoria Station, and put you on the boat-train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat-train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's better. Holmes has taken a railway guide from the shelf and is consulting it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sending me back to Brussels?   Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Valladon, you must understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Holmes, agitated) I came here to find my husband -- you were going to help me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my dear. But circumstances have changed --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great detective! Well, maybe this case is too small for you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary. It's being handled at a much higher level --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I won't go back to Brussels. Maybe you're giving up, but I'm not. (tears welling up in her eyes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to go on looking for him. And nobody's going to stop me -- even if they try to kill me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up from railway guide)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you quite finished? If you recall, what I said was that we're going to put you on the boat-train -- I didn't say you were going to stay on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At 7:30, Mr. Holmes and Dr. Watson will be seen waving goodbye to Madame Valladon at Victoria Station. At eight-twelve, Mr. and Mrs. Ashdown accompanied by their valet John -- (a glance at Watson) -- will appear at Euston Station, and board the Highland Express to Inverness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs.... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving toward Holmes) Thank you. I'm sorry for what I said. (kisses him on cheek)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling through tears) I'll go and pack. She hurries off toward Watson's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (acidly) Maybe I should do it, since I'm the valet. Holmes replaces the railway guide on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, what exactly are you up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you like to put it in your chronicles, the game is afoot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what game? Are you really that interested in the Belgian engineer? Without answering, Holmes heads for his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or the wife of the Belgian engineer? Holmes, by this time in his bedroom, shuts the door. Gabrielle reappears from the other bedroom, carrying a glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like me very much, do you? She moves toward the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing of the sort. Quite the opposite... But there's more to this case than meets the eye -- By this time Gabrielle has picked up her parasol from the couch, and is obviously searching about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking for something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My other glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He peers under the couch. Gabrielle moves toward the window, shakes the parasol, opens it a few times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it is. He comes up from under the couch with the missing glove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. She slowly starts to shut the parasol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the upstairs window of 221B we see Gabrielle shutting the parasol. CAMERA PULLS BACK TO INCLUDE the hansom parked across the street, and von Tirpitz watching. He signals to the cabbie, who is back on his perch. The cabbie flicks his whip, and the hansom takes off down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Highland Express is speeding northward through the moonlit landscape, its steam whistle hooting mournfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The upper and lower berths have been made up in the small, gaslit compartment. Gabrielle's dress is on a hanger, but there is no sign of her at the moment. Holmes is just pulling a night-shirt over his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.    You can look now. Gabrielle's head appears from under the covers of the lower berth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I embarrassing you, Mr. Holmes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all. Would it surprise you if I told you I once spent the night with 121 women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a very interesting case -- in a harem in Constantinople. He starts to climb up the ladder to the upper berth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the normal complement of passengers, men, women and children, of the middle and lower classes. The only unusual occupants are a group of seven MONKS, in brown habits and cowls. Watson, in valet's livery, comes down the aisle, proceeds toward a window-seat where he has left his umbrella and bowler. The resf of the bench is occupied by monks, as is the facing bench. As Watson tries to squeeze between them, he steps on the foot of one of the monks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, father -- I mean, friar -- or is it abbot? There is no answer from the monk. Watson picks up his bowler, settles himself in his seat, starts to fan himself with his hat. He turns sociably to the monk beside him, who is absorbed in his Bible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going to Scotland, you gentlemen?   So are we... As he fans himself the ear-pieces of his stethoscope, which is coiled inside the crown of his bowler, dangle down. He quickly shoves them back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a valet. My master and mistress and I are our way to Inverness. Ever been there? Beautiful country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monk looks up from his Bible, points to his lips, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, forgive me. You must be one of those orders that's taken the vow of silence. Trappists, I believe you're called. The monk doesn't answer. Watson turns away, looks out the window -- but there's nothing to be seen. Then he folds, bored. He glances casually at the Bible in the monk's hands. The Good Book is opened to a page headed: JONAH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you're reading the book of Jonah. Funny - we were just talking about Johan this morning... (realizes the hopelessness of the conversation, breaks off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. He pulls down the shade, closes his eyes, tries to compose himself into sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes is stretched out in the upper berth, which is in darkness. In the lower, Gabrielle is propped up against a pillow, reading a magazine by the light of a gas lamp. Other magazines are scattered across her blanket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Women are never to be trusted entirely -- not the best of them. Holmes raises himself on his elbow, glances down over the edge of his berth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say it -- you did. According to Dr. Watson.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: He gave me some back issues of Strand Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: The good doctor is constantly putting words into my mouth.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: Then you deny it?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Not at all. I am not a whole-hearted admirer of womankind.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: I'm not very fond of them myself.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: The most affectionate woman I ever knew was a murderess.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: It was one of those passionate affairs -- at odd hours -- right in my laboratory. And all the time, behind my back, she was stealing cyanide to sprinkle on her husband's steak and kidney pie.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: You mustn't judge all women by --

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Of course not. Only the ones I was involved with. And I don't just mean professionally -- kleptomaniacs, nymphomaniacs, pyromaniacs. Take my fiancee, for instance --

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: Your fiancee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was the daughter of my violin teacher -- we were engaged to be married -- the invitations were out, I was being fitted for a tail-coat -- and twenty-four hours before the wedding, she died of influenza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just proves my contention that women are unreliable and not to be trusted. (a beat) Good night, Mrs. Ashdown. He pulls the curtain across his berth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mr. Ashdown. She closes her curtain, as the train whistle sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of the passengers in the car have fallen asleep, in various uncomfortable positions, including Watson. The monk beside Watson looks at him, to make sure he's out, then rises and moves toward a monk seated apart from the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper) Die Spur fuehrt nach Inverness. Die steigen dort aus. Dort muessen wir ihn finded -- den Valladon! The other monk looks up.   Under the cowl we recognize th face of von Tirpitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Highland Express is pulling out of the station. As the last car disappears, and the steam clears from the tracks, we see Holmes, Gabrielle and Watson on the platform. A BAGGAGEMAN is loading their luggage on a hand-cart, under Watson's supervision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see -- two, three, four -- Gabrielle removes her parasol, which has been inserted under the straps of her suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to baggageman) How do you get to Glennahurich?    How far is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glennahurich?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know -- a valley -- with a yew tree... ? Gabrielle casually opens her parasol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about a mile out of town. (a beat) Why would you be wanting to go there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if it's got a view, it might be a nice place for a picnic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's got a view, right enough -- but it's no place for a picnic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's a cemetary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle looks at Holmes. CAMERA PANS UP TOWARD an iron footbridge, spanning the railway tracks. Moving across it in single file are the seven cowled Trappist monks, with von Tirpitz in the lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a leaden sky, the yew trees which give the place its name brood over ancient gravestones. Holmes, Gabrielle and Watson come down an overgrown path, stop and look off. A rather meagre funeral procession is moving along the avenue which runs between the rows of graves. It consists of one normal-size pine coffin and two smaller ones, loaded on a cart which is being wheeled by a couple of workmen. Bringing up behind is a MINISTER, with an open prayer book in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a note of excitement) The three boxes. Is that it, Holmes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two small ones -- they must be children's coffins. Holmes starts to cut across between the graves, Gabrielle and Watson following. At the grave-site, the workmen are removing the coffins from the cart. There is one large grave, two smaller ones. A couple of grave-diggers stand by respectfully, caps in hands. Holmes, Gabrielle and Watson come up behind a nearby headstone, stop and watch. At the grave-site, the minister is finishing the service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... earth to earth, ashes to ashes, dust to dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In sure and certain hope of the resurrection to eternal life through our Lord, Jesus Christ. Amen. The workmen trundle the cart off, the minister following. The grave-diggers don their caps, pick up their shovels. From their vantage point, Holmes, Gabrielle and Watson are watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sad -- and rather odd. There are no flowers -- and no mourners. The grave-diggers have finished filling in the graves when Holmes, Gabrielle and Watson come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working you hard, Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. This is healthy country. Sometimes you sit around for weeks with nothing to do. Then you get three in one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An accident. Aye. Father and two sons, they say -- they were found floating in the loch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Local people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Nobody around here knows them. The story is that their boat capsized in a swell -- but I don't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you believe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may think I'm an old fool or an old drunk -- but I've living around Loch Ness all my life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to tell us it was the monster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right. MacLarnin saw the kids' faces when they were pulled out of the water -- looked like old men -- must've died of fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it? Last Easter Sunday my wife and me, we were on our way to services, when suddenly... But what's the use? He picks up a white-washed wooden cross, plants it at the head of the grave. The other grave-digger has inserted smaller crosses into the other two mounds of earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking some coins out of his pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are, Dad. (hands them to the grave- digger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you... You look like nice people. If you're wanting a holiday in Scotland, go to Loch Lomond, go to Holy Loch -- but stay away from Loch Ness. He and his partner shoulder their shovels, move off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snorting) To think that people still believe in that nonsense. Here we are, living in the Nineteenth Century --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ashamed to admit it -- but I was relieved when he mentioned a father and two boys. It could possibly have anything to do with Emile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would appear not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: However, there still remains the clue of the castle and the red runner -- wherever it may be. They are about to get under way when suddenly Holmes stops them. Coming down the avenue toward them are four small boys, in knickerbockers and caps, carrying bouquets of flowers. Without a word, Holmes draws Gabrielle and Watson back to their hiding place, behind the headstone. The four boys approach the freshly-filled graves. They remove their caps, lay their flowers on each of the two small graves, then kneel down and bow their heads in prayer. From their position behind the headstone, Holmes, Watson and Gabrielle are watching the four boys, who have their backs to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they're unidentified graves, why are those boys bringing flowers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's their brothers who have just been buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Their brothers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they're not boys. They're as tall as they'll ever grow. Hand me some pebbles, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pebbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks some up from the ground, hands them to Holmes, who tosses them in the direction of the graves. The pebbles strike a granite cross. At the sound, the four boys simultaneously turn their heads over their shoulders. Despite their slight bodies they have the features of mature men. Gabrielle and Watson react to the sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are -- how do you say it in English? -- nains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Midgets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) Boys with the faces of old men...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still don't see --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would it help if I told you they were acrobats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you remember a tumbling act -- six brothers -- missing from the circus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes -- that case you turned down -- I completely forgot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of us are cursed with memories like flypaper. And stuck there is a staggering of miscellaneous date, mostly useless. The four midgets have now risen, and putting on their caps, move off down the avenue. Holmes, Gabrielle and Watson emerge from their place of concealment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (worriedly) Mr. Holmes, is those are not children, then -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite. The question now is -- who's in the third grave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point of a crowbar digs under the edge of a coffin lid, which starts to give with a squealing protest of nails. CAMERA PULLS BACK TO REVEAL Holmes, standing in the large grave, from which the earth has been removed. Kneeling beside the grave, watching anxiously, are Gabrielle and Watson, the latter holding a bullseye lantern. Holmes pries the lid open, disclosing the corpse of a middle-aged man. His arms are folded across his chest, and on the third finger of his left hand is a wedding ring similar to Gabrielle's. From the picture of him we have seen earlier, we recognize the face as that of Emile Valladon. Gabrielle lets out a piercing scream, collapses in a faint. Watson catches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes!   She's fainted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preoccupied) Hand me that lantern. Watson passes down the lantern, and Holmes slowly shines the beam along the length of the coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is Valladon, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously. What is not so obvious is why his wedding ring has turned green --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lantern beam now reveals that laid out at Valladon's feet are three canaries -- their plumage bleached a grey- white color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and why there are three dead canaries in the coffin. White canaries.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An open carriage is proceeding along the driveway toward the hotel, scatting a flock of sheep grazing nearby. Watson is sitting beside the coachman. Holmes and Gabrielle are in the passenger seat, their luggage is strapped to the back. Through the trees which line the road we glimpse Loch Ness, which is partly obscured by a low-lying mist. The carriage pulls up in front of the hotel, which is identified by a sign above the entrance, and Holmes, Watson and Gabrielle get out.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL REGISTER
dialogues.text: Holmes' hand is writing: Mr. And Mrs. Ashdown and valet, London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MANAGER, in kilts, is just opening the curtains -- disclosing a view of the mist-shrouded lake through the window. The room is on the second floor, and is furnished in a style which has been described as Scotch Baronial -- twin beds with a night-table between them, wardrobe, chiffonier, desk, a couple of chairs, and several mounted stags' heads. Holmes and Gabrielle are in the room, Watson is bringing their bags through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a lovely view of the loch from here -- as soon as the morning mist rolls away. (crosses to desk, picks up guide book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you've a mind to do any sight-seeing, here's a guide to the local points of interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. The manager starts toward the door, nodding to Watson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, please. I will show you to your room. Watson picks up his suitcase, follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager and Watson come out, the latter shutting the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you're putting me in the basement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, your room is in the attic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the privy that's in the basement. Watson grunts as the manager leads him up a narrow flight of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes removes his coat, turns to Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I have your wedding ring, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gabrielle tearfully removes her ring, hands it to Holmes. From his vest pocket he now produces Valladon's ring -- the copper has a greenish tinge to it. He crosses to the window, compares the two rings in the light. Gabrielle sinks down on the edge of one of the beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as I thought. There is a distinct difference in color between your ring and your husband's. (a sob from Gabrielle) Which leads me to believe that the cause of death was not drowning... (Gabrielle is now crying) I wish you would stop that. (crossing to her) Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's not easy. But you must remember that we're that nice couple from London, on Holiday in the Highlands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a final sniffle) I'll try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's much better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. She manages a tentative smile.   Holmes looks at her for long moment, then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gruffly) Now, if I may proceed without further interruptions --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from off) Mr. Ashdown!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson comes dashing down the narrow stairs from the attic, races toward teh door of Holmes' room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ashdown! He flings the door open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson bursts in breathlessly. WATSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes! I saw it! I saw it from the attic! It's out there in the lake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking around desperately) The telescope. Where's the telescope?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monster!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monster? Watson fishes a small telescope out of Holmes' suitcase, rushes through the open French window to the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson focuses the telescope on the lake.

dialogues.speaker: LOCH NESS THROUGH TELESCOPE
dialogues.text: Through the swirling mist which clings to the surface of the lake, a shadowy figure with a long, monster-like neck can be see gliding along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson almost drops the telescope in excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is!    There it is! Holmes joins him on the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look for yourself. He hands the telescope to Holmes. Gabrielle comes up to the window behind them. Holmes trains the telescope on the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See it?    See it?

dialogues.speaker: LOCH NESS
dialogues.text: Holmes' eye slowly scans the lake, but there is no sign of Watson's monster -- just the rolling mist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes lowers the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing? He grabs the telescope from Holmes, looks toward the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone?   Maybe it was never there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to you -- I saw it -- clear as anything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson, as you so succinctly put it, we are living in the Nineteenth Century -- He steps back into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson comes halfway through the French window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that grave-digger was right -- the swell, and the boat overturning --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur Valladon may have been found in the lake -- but he did not drown. He died of asphyxiation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Asphyxiation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up wedding rings) There is only one substance that can turn a copper ring green and bleach the color out of canaries -- chlorine gas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may be. But the fact remains that I saw something out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A figment of your imagination. Now let us be logical. The only concrete lead we have is the reference to the castle -- (picks up guide book from desk, opens it to map)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The question is, which castle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call yourself logical?   You're the least logical man I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you say it's a figment of my imagination, when for years you've been saying I have no imagination whatsoever! He looks at Holmes almost triumphantly.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Holmes, Gabrielle, and Watson bicycling away from the hotel. Holmes, in knickerbockers and a Norfolk jacket, and Gabrielle, holding her parasol, are on a tandem. Watson is behind them, on a bicycle with a picnic basket attached to the rack. He is in his valet's outfit, with metal clips around his trouser cuffs. The three of them bicycling past a long stone wall. They pedal up to an imposing castle.   Holmes dismounts, knocks on the front door. Our trio bicycling through a copse of trees. They approach another castle. On a steep road, they ride through a flock of sheep. They are proceeding along a causeway, away from a third castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes and Gabrielle are sitting on a blanket, the contents of the picnic basket spread before them, having lunch. Watson is pouring the wine. Their bicycles are resting nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have so far investigated  eight drafty castles -- had our bicycles  attacked by sheep and our ears assaulted  by bagpipes -- and we are exactly where  we started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gabrielle) Would you like some cranberry sauce, dear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, dear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you pass the cranberry sauce, please, John?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, dear. As he does so, he catches sight of something o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling) I say there. Good afternoon.     Remember me? On the road above, approaching a bridge which spans the lake where it narrows into a stream, are the seven Trappist monks, walking slowly in single file. Watson waves to them, but the monks pay no attention to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Holmes) Some chaps I met on the train. We had a long conversation -- or rather, I had a long conversation -- because they're not allowed to talk -- Trappists, you know. Just study their Bibles. You'll never guess what the one next to me was reading -- the Book of Jonah -- isn't that odd?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking after the monks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite. As he turns back, he notices that Gabrielle is manipulating her parasol in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, dear? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bee. She continues to work the parasol, alternately opening it and partially closing it. On the bridge von Tirpitz, who is at the rear of the file of monks, glances back toward the lakeshore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a promontory jutting into Loch Ness stand the remains of a medieval fortress. Around the Tower, the Motte, and the ruins of the East wall, wooden scaffolding has been erected, and a couple of dozen men are engaged in what appears to be repair work. Amidst the rubble of the Nether Bailey, an encampment of tents has been set up. Holmes, Gabrielle and Watson come bicycling up along a fence on the heights overlooking the castle, dismount in front of the locked gates. Attached to the gatepost is a sign reading: WARNING: No Unauthorized Person Permitted Beyond This Point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't think we have to bother with this castle. It's just a pile of rubble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why are they taking precautions? She points to the sign -- and to a guard coming up the driveway, with a couple of huge mastiffs on leashes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, indeed? (turning the tandem around) Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When rebuffed at the front door, one's only choice is to try the tradesmen's entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, Gabrielle and Watson are coming up a path from the lakeside, leading their bicycles. They lean the cycles against a ruined wall, start across the courtyard. A middle-aged MAN in kilts emerges from the tumbled-down gatehouse, comes toward them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.   No visitors allowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you the guide here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The castle is closed to the public while work is going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's being restored by the Society for the Preservation of Scottish Monuments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too bad. I particularly wanted my wife to see Urquhart Castle. The tower is one of the most interesting examples of -- about 1400, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see -- was it built under James the Second or James the Third?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Thrid... If you come back next year, we'll be all done here, and I'll be glad to show you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the three of them move off, a canvas-topped wagon comes through the stone archway, stops at the front of the steps leading to the inner courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasant sort, isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleasant, but ignorant. He was off one hundred years and one James. (taps guide-book in his pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's actually 1500 and James the Fourth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's an official guide, shouldn't he know... ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's an official guide. They have now reached the wall against which they left their bicycles. Suddenly Holmes stops, attracted by the sound of birds chirping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen...   Do you hear anything, Watson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concentrating) No. Those birds are making too much of a racket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking off) They're not just birds -- they're our old friends. Watson and Gabrielle follow his gaze. From the back of the wagon, the carriers have removed the small bird-cage we saw in the mail-drop on Ashdown Street. They hand it to a workman, who starts up the steps with it. To another couple of workmen they pass down an open-sided crate in which rest two heavy glass bottles protected by wicker. Stencilled on the wooden slate of the crate are the words: SULPHURIC ACID - CORROSIVE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes is watching thoughtfully, Gabrielle and Watson are puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sulphuric acid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more we find out the less sense it makes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To a graduate chemist it makes a great deal of sense. Sulphuric acid, when exposed to salt-water, produces chlorine gas. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you mind clasping your hands, Watson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (obeying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little lower... Thank you. Watson has lowered his clasped hands, and Holmes uses them as a foothold to go scrambling up the scaffolding of the nearby wall. Reaching the top, he looks off in the direction of the tower. The workman carrying the canary cage, and the two carrying the crate of sulphuric acid are approaching the tower. A draw-bridge comes down, and the three men cross the moat and enter the tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That tower may be more interesting than I thought -- and not just architecturally. Out of the ruined gatehouse comes the guard with the two mastiffs on leashes. The dogs start to snarl viciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, I have a feeling we're redundant here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes leaps down from the scaffolding, wheels the tandem around, starts back in the direction from which they came. Gabrielle follows. Watson hurries after them with his bicycle, casting anxious glances over his shoulder as the dogs continue barking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has just gone down behind the hills, but there is still light in the sky. An ominous mist is beginning to settle on the water. Gabrielle is sitting in the stern of a rowboat, her parasol in her lap. She is wearing Holmes' Norfolk jacket over her dress to ward off the chill. On the rowing seat, facing her, are Watson and Holmes, the latter in his waistcoat. Their oars are pulled in, and they are watching Urquhart Castle, on the opposite side of the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have now observed the castle from the front, from the back, from the side, from land, from water... what now?  Are you planning to spend the night out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to catch your death of cold. (to Gabrielle) Wouldn't it be ironic if Holmes' last case were a case of pneumonia? (with an embarrassed chuckle) Sorry. Gabrielle glances past them, and her eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing off) What's that? Holmes and Watson turn their heads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About half a mile away, moving in and out of patches of drifting mist, is Watson's monster, its long reptillian neck cutting through the water. Watson leaps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes! Holmes grabs his arm, pulls him back into his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick, Watson. After it! He grabs his oar, and Watson belatedly joins in. They strain at the oars, setting a course which will intercept the monster.  Gabrielle leans forward in her seat, trying to peer past them through the curtains of mist. The monster is much closer now -- no more than a quarter of a mile away. Suddenly Watson stops rowing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, what are we doing?   We should be going away from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep rowing, dammit! Watson resumes pulling on his oar.   As they row, Holmes looks over his shoulder. The monster has started to submerge. Its head disappears beneath the surface of the water, and the wake it leaves behind soon trails off into the mist. Holmes ships his oar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've lost it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops rowing) At least you admit there's an it, not just a figment of my imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He listens intently. There is only the sound of water slapping against the side of the boat. The mist is heavier now, and billowing around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Watson) Do you have your stethoscope with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never without it. He removes his bowler, unwinds the stethoscope from the inside the crown, hands it to Holmes. Holmes plugs in the ear-pieces, leans over the side of the boat, extends the other end of the stethoscope to the surface of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can hear something... We become aware of the faint beating of engines, accompanied by a bubbling sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting closer -- closer -- Suddenly the surface of the water breaks, about twenty yards away from them, and the head and neck of the monster rear up from the depths. Watson is first to notice it and jumps to his feet, making choking noises. Gabrielle sees it and screams. Watson grabs an oar, throws it at the monster as it comes past. The backwash hits the boat broadside, rocking it, and Holmes, Watson and Gabrielle are spilled into the lake. The monster moves away from them, heading in the general direction of the castle. It disappears into the mist. Holmes is the first to come up, looks around, sees Gabrielle surfacing a few yards away, swims to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I lost my parasol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Watson? He glances around, sees Watson's bowler floating nearby, swims over to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson? He lifts the hat -- but Watson isn't under it. As Gabrielle hoists herself into the boat, Watson clambers over the other side. After a moment Holmes joins them, and they sit there, sopping wet and breathing heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have come face to   face with man-eating tigers -- I was once   caught in a stampede of wild elephants --   India, you know -- but I wasn't half as   frightened. This beast seems to have   a personal grudge against us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just hope it doesn't come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think it will. (pointing off) Look! They glance in the indicated direction. There is no sign of the monster. But the mist has momentarily lifted to reveal the castle, and an odd sight greets their eyes -- the wooden scaffolding in front of the tower is slowly rising into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed) What strange goings-on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really. My guess is that the monster, after a hard day's work, has returned home for his supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scaffolding in front of the tower slowly descends back into the place, as mist once more engulfs the castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, in a different suit   of clothes, is pacing acros the room, whistling the main   theme from "Swan Lake." He stops before the open French   window, gazes out toward t lake. Gabrielle is propped    up in bed, a blanket drawn to her chin, watching him.    Watson, who has changed int a pair of kilts, is standing   in front of the fireplace, warming his backside. Gabrielle glances at Watson, suppresses a giggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. But would you believe that you can't borrow a decent pair of trousers in this place? Holmes resumes pacing, and Watson becomes aware of his whistling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to confide in us? No answer from Holmes.    Watson turns to Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever he starts whistling, I know he's getting close to a solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing new, actually. We've come across this situation before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have?   Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the ballet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ballet?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: There's a lake -- and there's a castle -- and there's a swan that isn't really a swan -- or, in this case, a monster that isn't really a monster --

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: Then what is it?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: What is it indeed that feeds on canary birds and sulphuric acid, and has an engine for a heart?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: An engine?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: The stethoscope is a very sensitive instrument, and water is an excellent conductor of sound. There is no doubt that what we are dealing with is a mechanical monster.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Not only is it equipped with an artificial heart, it also has artificial lungs. Judging from the bubbles on the surface of the lake, it uses some form of air pump.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: You think my husband was involved in all this?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Yes, Madame Valladon.    I'm sure of it.

dialogues.speaker: WATSON
dialogues.text: But why would anybody build a mechanical monster? Just to scare people?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Not very likely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did they try to keep me from finding my husband? And why was he buried anonymously?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I have a pretty good notion of what they're up to -- the Society for the Preservation of Scottish Monuments -- better known as the Diogenes Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Diogenes Club? There is a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. The door opens and the hotel manager enters, holding a magnum of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ashdown, I have a bottle of champagne for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crossing to him) A bottle of champagne? I didn't order it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, indeed. You are to deliver it. These are my instructions. He hands the magnum to Holmes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instructions from whom?   Deliver it where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't know, sir. But there's a carriage waiting for you downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you have the right Mr. Ashdown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) Quite sure, Mr. Holmes. He turns and exits.   Holmes taps the bottle of champagne thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Watson, I would say the curtain is going up on the last act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like the sound of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please be careful. As Holmes starts toward the door, Watson reaches into his sporran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better take this with you. He produces a revolver, holds it out to Holmes.    Holmes ignores it, exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gig is waiting in front of the entrance, and leaning against it is the guide we saw earlier at Urquhart. Holmes comes out, carrying the champagne bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's minding the castle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better get on.     It's late. Holmes climbs into the gig, and the guide moutns the seat beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?    Some sort of party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't be disappointed in the guest list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the host?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jonah. He flicks the reins. The horse starts off at a trot, and the gig turns into the driveway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they drive along, Holmes glances at the guide, who is grim and uncommunicative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gig, with its two passengers, proceeds along the lakeshore, approaching the entrance to Urquhart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A workman is lighting a couple of torches attached to the ruined gatehouse when the gig comes through the archway. The guide reins up the horse in front of the steps leading to the inner courtyard -- which are now covered with a narrow red carpet. The guide nods to Holmes, who dismounts, starts up the steps, examining the red carpet. As he reaches the top, he looks off. The strip of red carpet runs across the courtyard, lit by torches planted in the ground. A couple of workmen are are unrolling the rest of the carpet toward the entrance of the tower. As Holmes passes one of the tents, the flap opens and Mycroft steps out, dressed in his inevitable frock coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ashdown, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) The red runner, I presume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicates carpet) You shouldn't have gone to all this trouble just for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not for you. (calling into tent) McKeller. (to Holmes) May I have the champagne, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him bottle) 1886 -- not a very good vintage, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mediocre.   But then again, it's not for drinking. A black-suited MAN emerges from the ten, and Mycroft gives him the champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tie it up, will you? The man moves off toward the tower.   Mycroft pulls back the flap of the tent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In here. Holmes passes inside, Mycroft following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is lit by a kerosene lamp suspended from the ridge- pole. There are several cots, one of them with the bedding rolled up. Resting on the stripped cot is a trunk with the name E. VALLADON painted on it. Lying on a table, among a group of engineering models, are Gabrielle's parasol and Watson's stethoscope. There are also a couple of drafting tables, with plans and blueprints tacked to them. Holmes moves around the tent, taking all this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting -- and educational.

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: Despite my most emphatic warning, you persisted in meddling. It would have served you right if you'd all drowned.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Sorry to be so unobliging. (stops beside torch) E. Valladon... H'mm.

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: (indicating parasol   and stethoscope) I imagine this belongs to    the pretty lady, and this belongs to    your valet... We found them floating in    the lake.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Speaking about things floating in the lake --

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: How much do you know -- or think you know?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I think you're testing some sort of underwater craft -- camouflauged to mislead the gullible. I think it's an experimental model, operated by a crew of midgets. I think it is powered by sulphuric acid batteries, and uses canaries to detect escaping gas... Altogether a strange contraption.

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: Not quite that unique. Right now, four countries are trying to develop what we call a submersible. But none of them could solve the critical problem -- how to stay submerged long enough to make it effective.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: What does the Good Book say? "And Jonah lived in the belly of that fish for three days and three nights."

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: That was our goal. And thanks to Valladon's air-pump, we got a jump on the rest of them. It's a highly complex system of filtration -- so we had a series of trials --

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: And at least one error.

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: During a test run in Moray Firth, pressure caused a leak in the hull. Sea water mixed with the acid in the batteries to produce chlorine gas. Before they could reach the surface, Valladon and the crew were dead.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: So you had them buried in unmarked graves, to preserve your secret.

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: It was essential to keep the information from your client.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: You went to all those lengths to prevent Madame Valladon from fiding her husband?

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: Your client isn't Madame Valladon -- it's the Imperial German Government. They were after the Belgian engineer -- or rather, his invention. They knew he was employed by us, but they couldn't find out where -- so they enlisted the best brain in England to help them. You, my dear brother, have been working for the Wilhelmstrasse.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: And Madame Valladon -- what part did she play in all this?

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: Madame Valladon is dead.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mycroft crosses to the trunk, opens the lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Germans disposed of her three weeks ago, in Brussels. This is Gabrielle Valladon. He hands Holmes a small, framed photograph. Holmes looks at it with apprehension, as well he should: the picture is of a somewhat matronly woman, not the glamorous Gabrielle. Holmes lowers  the photograph. Behind it, Mycroft is glaring at him with customary arrogance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman who was brought to your house in the middle of the night -- apparently fished out of the Thames -- and apparently suffering from amnesia -- is, in fact, Ilse von Hoffmanstal, one of their most skillful agents. Am I going too fast for one of the "best brains in England?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. As Mycroft continues, Holmes picks up Ilse's water-soaked parasol and examines it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They planted her on you quite neatly, I must admit, so that you could lead them to their objective, the air pump. Very much like using a hog to find truffles. And now perhaps you'd care to join me. I am expecting a certain royal personage from Balmoral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coach and escort approach the castle. Painted on the door of the coach are the initials "V.R."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entourage enters the castle courtyard and stops. Footmen open the door and bow to the lone passenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Waiting on top of the steps, outside the tent, are Mycroft and Holmes. Lined up on the other side of the torch-lit red carpet are half a dozen scientists, in their best clothes. Out of the coach steps a familiar figure -- Her Majesty, QUEEN VICTORIA, Defender of the Faith, Empress of India. She is 69 years old, and dressed entirely in black. Mycroft comes down the carpeted steps to meet her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Majesty. He bows. The Queen extends her hand to him, and he touches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust you had a pleasant journey, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
