dialogues.text: It was long and it was tedious. And it had better be worth our while, Mr. Holmes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can assure you, Ma'am, it will be. A lady-in-waiting and a uniformed equerry have now descended from the coach. Mycroft leads the party up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what is this curious ship we are supposed to christen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We call it a submersible, Ma'am.    It travels under water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under water?    What a fantastic idea. They have now reached the top of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: Ma'am, may present some of the scientists who were responsible for this achievement. J.W. Ferguson, naval architect --

dialogues.speaker: FIRST SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: (bowing) Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: Professor Simpson, our leading expert on hydraulics --

dialogues.speaker: SECOND SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: (bowing) Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: W.W. Prescott, co-inventor of the revolving periscope --

dialogues.speaker: THIRD SCIENTIST
dialogues.text: (bowing) Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: And this is Sir Arthur Grisby, our authority on maritime ballistics --

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: We don't claim to understand any of this. But England is proud of you, gentlemen. To think that man can now observe fish in their native habitat --

dialogues.speaker: MYCROFT
dialogues.text: (trying to correct her) Well, not exactly, Ma'am --

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN VICTORIA
dialogues.text: -- and underwater plants and coral reefs -- (noticing Holmes) Young man -- what was your contribution to this project?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it was rather negligible, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Queen) This is my brother, Sherlock, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes. Sherlock Holmes. We have been following your exploits with great interest. Holmes bows, touches the Queen's extended hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you engaged in one of your fascinating cases at the moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a manner of speaking, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When can we expect to read Dr. Watson's account of the case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope never, Ma'am. It has not been one of my more successful endeavors. Mycroft signals to a bagpiper, who starts playing HIELAN' LADDIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, the ceremonies are about to begin. (to Mycroft) Now where is this underwater ship of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to tower) In the dungeon, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dungeon? What a peculiar place to keep it. (turning to the others) Well, let us get on with it, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mycroft leads the Queen along the red runner toward the tower. Holmes follows, then the lady-in-waiting and the equerry, then the scientists. As they cross the inner courtyard, the Highland piper falls in ahead of the procession, leads them toward the drawbridge. Then he steps aside,  as the royal party crosses the drawbridge and passes through the door of the tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high-ceilinged rock chamber, with a spiral iron staircase leading down. The floor is a concrete ramp, the lower end of it covered with water. Beyond is the entrance from the Loch, camouflaged by scaffolding and vegetation. On the upper part of the ramp is a small, primitive submarine, resting on wheels. Prominently lettered on the bow is the name H.M.S. JONAH, and suspended by a rope from the prow is the magnum of champagne which Holmes delivered. Along the sides are torpedo tubes, and fitted over the conning tower is the head and neck of the "monster" we saw in the lake. Present are half a dozen naval personnel, commanded by an officer. As the royal party comes down the spiral staircase, the officer snaps to attention. Mycroft is in the lead, followed by the Queen, Holmes, the lady-in- waiting, the equerry and the scientists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There she, Ma'am. Her Majesty's Ship Jonah. The four surviving midgets appear on the deck, in wool jerseys and navy caps. They start pulling on a chain which slowly raises the detachable head-and-neck of the monster toward the ceiling, disclosing the conning tower and the periscope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what, may we ask, is the purpose of that hideous gargoyle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's merely a decoy, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUEEN VICTORIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. To frighten away the sharks, we imagine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something of the sort... The crew will now demonstrate the workings of the submersible. A SAILOR of normal height appears on the deck of the sub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand to. The midgets scramble down the hatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't they rather small for sailors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are. But because of the size of the craft, the Navy made an exception.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They should make it a rule. It's quite fatiguing to pin on all those medals while standing on our toes. There is the sound of the engines starting. Mycroft leads the Queen to an open bulkhead in the side of the sub, with Holmes and rest of the party close behind. Inside, all is noise and confusion. Metal rods are dipping into glass jars of sulphuric acid, complicated machinery is driving the propeller shaft, bellows are inflating and deflating, etc. The midgets are at their stations in the cramped quarters, pulling switches, oiling the engines, operating the periscope. Overhead is a cageful of canaries, all chirping away. Mycroft points out the various features to the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the main engine, which propels it under water at the rate of two knots -- the stabilizing mechanism -- the multi- stage compressor -- the ballast tank trimmer -- the air-pump which filters and recirculates the air --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How charming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air pump, Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) The canaries. Must make the crew feel at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am. These are the levers for firing the torpedoes, which are accurate up to as much as 120 feet -- the periscope for scanning the surface of the water --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where is the glass bottom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The what, Ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The glass bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know -- to see the fist --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and the plants and the corals --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not quite the idea, Ma'am. H.M.S. Jonah is being commissioned as a warship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A warship? (waving her hand) Stop that noise. Stop it! At a signal from Mycroft, the sub engines are turned off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, if I may explain --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Admiralty regards this craft as the ultimate weapon in naval warfare. It can seek out enemy ships and destroy them -- with these torpedoes -- while remaining completely invisible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean in can fire at other vessels while under water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without any warning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And without showing her colors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed, Ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Holmes, we are not amused. (Mycroft stares at her) It is unsportsmanlike, it is un-English, and it is in very poor taste. We will have none of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon, Ma'am? He exchanges a look with Holmes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes we despair of the state of the world. What will scientists think of next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's precisely it, Ma'am. At this very moment the Germans under Count von Zeppelin, are experimenting with a dirigible --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: QUEEN VICTORIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dirigible? And what, pray, is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rigid balloon, which could fly over London and drop a bomb on Buckingham Palace. It is being developed at the express orders of Kaiser Wilhelm the Second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. We refuse to believe that our grandson Willie would do a thing like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have conclusive proof, Ma'am. Our agent in Friedrichshafen, a man named Ibbetson, actually saw the dirigible, and made a drawing of it. Unfortunately, he was apprehended before he could cross the border.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating sub) Nevertheless, we don't want any part of this beastly invention. Get rid of it! Scuttle it! The sooner the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I point out, Ma'am --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't concern yourself about that dirigible dropping bombs on us. We shall write a very sharp note to the Kaiser. (to equerry) Now we wish to return to Balmoral. She starts toward the spiral staircase. The equerry precedes her up the stairs, the lady-in-waiting follows, the scientists trail after them. Mycroft and Holmes linger behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mycroft, it seems we have both been undone by a woman. (Mycroft is staring at the sub)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that superb engineering, and all that cunning espionage, for nought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not necessarily. If the Germans want that submersible so badly, why don't we give it to them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it to them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Invite them aboard for the final journey -- seven hundred feet -- straight down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how are you going to arrange that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm rather counting on you to do it. Since you are on such intimate terms with Fraulein von Hoffmanstal. O.s., the bagpiper resumes playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we say goodbye to Her Majesty? He starts up the spiral staircase.    Holmes follows slow and thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gig, with the quide driving and Holmes beside him, comes up the driveway, stops in front of the entrance. Holmes hops down, and twirling Gabrielle's parasol in his hand, walks into the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the half-light, Gabrielle can be seen asleep in her bed. She is wearing the pink negligee with the maribou feathers, which has slipped halfway off her shoulders. The other bed has not been slept in. The door from the corridor opens and Holmes steps in, carrying the parasol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to Gabrielle's bed, looks down at her for a long moment, adjusts the negligee with the tip of the parasol. The he moves to the French window, opens it, glances out.

dialogues.speaker: LAKEFRONT
dialogues.text: The seven Trappist monks are standing on the shore, silhouetted against the water, watching the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes withdraws from the window , looks at the sleeping Gabrielle, then casually swings the parasol, hitting a metal lamp-shade overhead. Gabrielle sits up abruptly in bed, clutching her negligee around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that. But as long as you're up -- what is the German word for castle? Schloss, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how would you say under the castle? Unter das Schlss? Or die Schloss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. My German isn't that good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating) Your Trappist friends are out there waiting to hear from you -- it's a chilly morning -- we don't want to keep them standing around too long, do we, Fraulein Hoffmanstal? (Gabrielle looks at him without answering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come now. It's too late to play cat and mouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) Unter dem Schloss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (holding out parasol)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your signalling device -- it's a bit damp, I'm afraid -- would you care to let them know where they can find the submersible? (Gabrielle makes no move to take the parasol)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No? Then I'll just have to do it myself. (moving toward window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only hope my Morse code is adequate to the occasion. Keeping well to one side of the open window, he extends the parasol outside, opens it, starts sending out a series of long and short signals.

dialogues.speaker: LAKEFRONT
dialogues.text: von Tirpitz and the other monks strain their eyes in the direction of the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL
dialogues.text: Outside the hotel window, Gabrielle's parasol can be seen flashing the message UNTER DEM SCHLOSS in Morse code -- but it is not apparent that Holmes is doing the signalling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Holmes continues opening and closing the parasol, Gabrielle gets out of bed, comes up beside him. Holmes finishes the message, shuts the parasol, draws it back into the room. Then he looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: LAKEFRONT
dialogues.text: The monks turn away from the hotel, and with von Tirpitz in the lead, move off along the shore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes steps back from the window, faces Gabrielle.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Well, it's up to the good monks now. You can consider your part of the mission accomplished, Fraulein Hoffmanstal.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: You're all wrong about me.   My name isn't Hoffmanstal.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: It isn't?

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: It's von Hoffmanstal.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: I stand corrected.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: (glancing toward window) I suppose once they're in the castle... It must amuse you, Mr. Holmes, Trappists walking into a trap.

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: It's more amusing than that. Once in the castle, they will encounter surprisingly little resistance -- it will take but a small bottle of chloroform to overcome the guards.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: (skeptically) You mean you're going to let them have the air-pump?

dialogues.speaker: HOLMES
dialogues.text: Better than that. We're going to let them have the submersible. They will find it with its engines running, all set to go. I assume they're all expert sailors? And since there is a German battleship cruising off the coast of Scotland, I expect they'll try to sail it out of the lock and rendezvous at sea.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: Did you say try to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would suggest you get your things together. Mycroft will be here to take you into custody. He opens her suitcase, which is on the baggage rack at the foot of the bed. Gabrielle watches him for a beat, then crosses to the wardrobe, starts taking her clothes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never had you fooled for a moment, did I? You knew right from the beginning -- when the cabbie brought me to Baker Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see -- not quite that soon. He stretches out on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's so funny. I asked for this assignment, you know. I was scheduled to go to Japan, but I couldn't resist the challenge of coming up against the best. I'm sorry I didn't give you a closer game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just being kind.   I failed miserably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all have occasional failures. Fortunately, Dr. Watson never writes about mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson, back in his valet's outfit again, comes bounding down the narrow stairs from the attic, races toward the door of Holmes' room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes!   Holmes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bright sunlight now floods the room.   Gabrielle, fully dressed, is standing in front of the  mirror, putting on her hat. Her packed bag has been set   out in the middle of the room, and resting on it is the  parasol. The door bursts open and Watson dashes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes! In his haste he trips over the bag, goes down. As he picks himself up again, Gabrielle points toward the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes is leaning against the parapet, scanning the lake through his telescope. Watson appears through the open French window behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Holmes, I saw it again -- that thing -- it came from the castle -- it's out there

dialogues.speaker: LOCH NESS
dialogues.text: A trial of bubbles is moving along the surface. Suddenly there is a muffled explosion from below, and a geyser of water shoots up into the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes slowly lowers the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was out there. Now it's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forever.   Look for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: LOCH NESS
dialogues.text: There is a great turbulence in the water. Up to the surface pops the bottle of christening champagne, with rope and ribbons still attached. Then a copy of the Bible pops up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bottle of champagne?... and a Bible?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all that's left of H.M.S. Jonah. He steps through the window as a puzzled Watson lowers the telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson follows Holmes in from the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would seem that somebody carelessly loosened the bolts of the submersible. What a fitting end for Trappists -- now they are resting in eternal silence at the bottom of the lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gabrielle) Do you know what he's talking about? Through the open doorway comes Mycroft.   In the corridor behind him is one of his aides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fraulein von Hoffmanstal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Holmes. I'm all ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's one thing I like about the Prussians, it's their punctuality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's one thing I dislike about the British, it's their climate. I understand your jails are quite damp -- and your heating facilities totally inadequate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are. But you're not going to jail. You're going back to Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Germany?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be conducted to the Swiss-German border, and be exchanged for one of our agents -- a man named Ibbetson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't thank me. Thank my brother.      It was his idea. Gabrielle looks at Holmes, but he avoids her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gabrielle) Frankly, I think we are making a very poor deal. You much better than most operatives working for British intelligence. (turning to Holmes) Don't you agree, Sherlock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with a small but gallant bow to Gabrielle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And better than some consulting detectives. Mycroft signals to his aide, who comes in from the corridor and picks up Gabrielle's bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gabrielle) Shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching for parasol) I'll take that. (to Holmes and Watson) Gentlemen. She turns and walks out the door, Mycroft following. Watson's bewilderment has now reached monumental proportions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (folding his arms) All right, Holmes -- you don't have to explain anything to me, if you don't want to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate that, Watson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, I'm only your official biographer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I don't think she'd care to have this story spread all over Strand Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The public has a right to know these things. If she's a German spy, why should we concern ourselves about her feelings? Holmes crosses to a small window overlooking the courtyard of the hotel, opens it, looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mycroft's aide comes out of the hotel with Gabrielle's suitcase, loads it into an open carriage waiting in front of the entrance. Gabrielle emerges, carrying her parasol, and accompanied by Mycroft. He helps her into the carriage, gets in beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The aide joins the coachman, and the carriage drives off. Gabrielle does not look back toward the hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes is framed in the open window, watching the carriage. Watson comes up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I promised not to write a word about it, would you enlighten me? As your friend -- as your valet -- HOLMES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet. I'm trying to read a personal message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage is moving away from the hotel. Gabrielle has her parasol over her shoulder, and it opens and closes, opens and closes.

dialogues.speaker: GABRIELLE
dialogues.text: She continues to signal with the parasol, unnoticed by Mycroft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson is straining forward to see out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is she saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly) Auf Wiedersehn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Auf Weider---? The nerve!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The carriage disappears down an avenue of trees, Gabrielle's parasol still flashing its message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is snow on the ground, and drifts of it piled up along the curbs. Traffic is light. Householders are shovelling the snow off the sidewalks, and pedestrians are hurrying along bundled up against the cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes, in his dressing gown, and Watson, in his smoking jacket, are at the breakfast table. There is snow on the window-sills, and a cozy fire is burning in the grate. Watson is reading the morning paper. Holmes is sorting through his mail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up envelope) H'mmm. A letter from the Diogenes Club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe Mycroft is putting you up for membership.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only to have the distinct pleasure of blackballing his brother. He has slit open the envelope. Watson watches him curiously as he reads the letter, but Holmes' face remains expressionless. Slowly he puts down the letter, rises, crosses to the window, stands there staring out into the wintry street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to finish your breakfast? Holmes doesn't answer. Watson takes a lump of sugar out of the bowl with a pair of tongs, drops it into his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then glancing over his shoulder to make sure Holmes isn't watching, he swivels the letter around with the tongs. It is written on Diogenes Club stationery, and reads: 9th December, 1888

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Sherlock, My sources in Tokyo inform me that Ilse von Hoffmanstal was arrested last week by the Japanese counter-intelligence service for spying on naval installations in Yokohama harbour. After a secret trial, she was summarily executed by a firing squad. It might interest you to know that The page ends at this point. Watson turns the sheet of paper over with the tongs. The letter continues on the other side. she had been living in Japan these past few months under the name of Mrs. Ashdown. Sincerely, Mycroft

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watson looks toward Holmes, who is still standing with his back to the room, gets up from the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holmes -- I'm terribly sorry about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, without turning) Where is it, Watson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a beat) In the files. May to July, 1885. Holmes turns to the bookshelves above the desk.   From a row of similar volumes, he slides out the three  files marked MAY, JUNE, and JULY 1885. Actually, it's   the medical bag, standing on end, with the spines of  three volumes pasted on the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're getting better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sets the bag down on the desk, opens it, takes out a bottle of cocaine. Watson watches him with compassion as he crosses to his bedroom with his cocaine, goes in, shuts the door. Footsteps are heard hurrying up the stairs, and after a moment there is a knock on the door. Watson approaches the door, opens it to reveal INSPECTOR LESTRADE -- a short, nervous man whose features are sharper than his mind. He is wearing an overcoat, his bowler is in his hands, and his fingers are drumming on the crown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Watson. (stepping in) Just happened to be in the neighborhood, and I thought --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it this time, Inspector Lestrade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've had three rather nasty murders in Whitechapel. All ladies of  easy virtue. You may read something about it -- the newspapers are referring to the killer as Jack the Ripper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I think I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of us at Scotland Yard were wondering if perhaps Mr. Holmes would be willing to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a glance toward the bedroom) I'm sorry, Lestrade. But at the moment, Holmes is working on another problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to hide his disappointment)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... Well, I just thought it was the kind of case that might interest him. I dare say we can solve it without his help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sure you will. From Holmes' bedroom comes the sound of a melancholy tune being played on the violin. Watson starts to ease Lestrade out of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, Lestrade. He shuts the door after him, listens to the sound of the violin for a moment. Then he crosses to the wicker chair, seats himself. He takes some sheets of paper out of the rack and places them on the writing arm, dips his pen in the inkwell, starts to write. The violin music continues OVER SCENE, infinitely romantic, infinitely sad.
